questions.text: A previously healthy 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of one episode of vomiting and severe headache since this morning. His mother says he also had difficulty getting dressed on his own. He has not had any trauma. The patient appears nervous. His temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 185/125 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is an abdominal bruit that is best heard at the right costovertebral angle. A complete blood count is within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography with doppler is used to confirm coarctation of the aorta. Although, coarctation of the aorta can also lead to hypertension in children, other symptoms such as hypotension and claudication of the lower extremities or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades are typically present. An abdominal bruit as in this boy, however, would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

An oral sodium loading test is used to confirm primary hyperaldosteronism. Although primary hyperaldosteronism is a common cause of secondary hypertension in young patients, symptoms of hypokalemia such as fatigue or muscle weakness are also typically present. Additionally, primary hyperaldosteronism would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

C) CORRECT:

CT angiography is a noninvasive imaging method that has high accuracy in confirming the diagnosis of fibromuscular dysplasia. Imaging would typically show a single or multiple stenoses of the renal arteries. Other imaging methods that can be used to diagnose FMD are duplex ultrasonography and magnetic resonance angiography. The choice of method depends mostly on expertise and availability at individual institutions. After this patient's blood pressure has been adequately controlled and the diagnosis has been confirmed, the renal artery stenosis should be treated with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum IGF-I levels are used in the evaluation of acromegaly. Although acromegaly can also cause secondary hypertension, it usually occurs in adults and is associated with other symptoms such as a large skull, coarsened features, and widened hands, fingers, and feet. Additionally, it would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit on examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum PTH levels are used in the diagnostic evaluation of hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism can also lead to hypertension due to progressive calcification of the arteries and heart muscle. However, it is typically associated with other findings such as nephrolithiasis, constipation, gastric ulcers, psychological symptoms (e.g., depression, fatigue), and/or bone, muscle, and joint pain. Additionally, primary hyperparathyroidism would not cause this patient's abdominal bruit.

F) INCORRECT:

A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used to confirm Cushing syndrome. While Cushing syndrome is also a common cause of secondary hypertension, it is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as obesity, hirsutism, and easily bruisable skin with stretch marks. Additionally, it would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit on examination.

G) INCORRECT:

Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are used to screen for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Although CAH can also cause secondary hypertension, it is often associated with precocious puberty and electrolyte abnormalities and would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit. Additionally, all newborns in the US are screened for CAH, so that a delayed diagnosis at age 10 would be unlikely.

H) INCORRECT:

Testing for urine catecholamines is used to confirm the diagnosis of neuroblastoma. Although neuroblastoma can also manifest with hypertension, nausea, and headaches, it typically also causes constitutional symptoms, such as failure to thrive, weight loss, and fever. In the majority of cases the tumor is located in the abdomen, palpable as an irregular abdominal mass and accompanied by abdominal pain and distention. An abdominal bruit on examination would not be expected. In addition, the tumor is more common in young children (1–2 years of age) and would be exceedingly rare in 10-year-old.
questions.hint: In a young patient with a hypertensive emergency (blood pressure 185/125 mm Hg, papilledema, severe headache, confusion, and vomiting) and an abdominal bruit on examination that is best heard at the right costovertebral angle, fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) should be suspected.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and blood pressure is 165/115 mm Hg. Her blood pressure measured 5 hours ago at home was 160/112 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 28-week gestation. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and hepatic transaminases are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin is not used as a first-line drug for seizure prophylaxis during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal hydantoin syndrome. Phenytoin is only used for seizure prophylaxis in patients who have preeclampsia with severe features if the preferred agent, magnesium sulfate, is contraindicated or not available.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril and angiotensin receptor blockers are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy because they can cause permanent renal damage in the fetus as well as congenital malformations of the cardiovascular system and/or CNS.

C) INCORRECT:

Strenuous exercise (e.g., weight lifting, high-intensity interval training) should be avoided in patients with preeclampsia. However, mild exercise (e.g., walking, stretching) may be beneficial in this patient group. Complete bed rest is associated with an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and is therefore not recommended in patients with hypertensive pregnancy disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Dietary modifications such as reduction of salt intake and a DASH diet are recommended for all patients with primary hypertension. However, they have not been shown to improve outcomes in patients with gestational hypertension, which is primarily due to placental angiogenic factors that negatively affect maternal endothelial function.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin can be initiated after 12 weeks' gestation to reduce the risk of preeclampsia in patients with certain high-risk features, such as a history of preeclampsia in a previous pregnancy, multiple pregnancy, diabetes mellitus (gestational or nongestational), preexisting hypertension, and/or autoimmune diseases. This patient already meets the diagnostic criteria for preeclampsia with severe features. Aspirin is solely used in the prophylaxis but not in the treatment of preeclampsia.

F) CORRECT:

Antihypertensive therapy should be initiated as soon as possible in patients with preeclampsia with severe features. Available options include intravenous hydralazine, intravenous labetalol, and oral nifedipine. Magnesium sulfate should also be administered for seizure prophylaxis. Patients between 24 weeks' and 34 weeks' gestation should also receive antenatal corticosteroid therapy for fetal maturation.

Management of patients with preeclampsia with severe features who are at < 34 weeks' gestation should be continued on an inpatient basis. Although expectant management is acceptable in these patients, delivery should not be delayed if there is maternal or fetal deterioration.
questions.hint: Preeclampsia with severe features can be diagnosed in patients at > 20 weeks' gestation who present with systolic blood pressure ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 110 mm Hg, even if other abnormalities characteristic of preeclampsia are absent on clinical or diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and swelling of the lower legs for 3 weeks. One year ago, he had an 85% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery, for which he received 2 stents. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C 5 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and arterial hypertension. Current medications include aspirin, metformin, and ramipril. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6500/mm3



Platelet count
188,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+
137 mEq/L


 Cl−
105 mEq/L

5.2 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL

110 mg/dL

3.9 mg/dL

3.6 g/dL


Hemoglobin A1C
6.5%


Urine

negative

A renal biopsy shows sclerosis in the capillary tufts and arterial hyalinosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy is the leading cause of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in high-income regions. While this patient has a history of diabetes, renal biopsy in diabetic nephropathy would typically show glomerular basement membrane thickening on light microscopy, with increased mesangial matrix and round eosinophilic nodules in the glomeruli (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules). In addition, diabetic nephropathy usually manifests with pronounced proteinuria. This patient's hemoglobin A1c of < 7% indicates well-controlled diabetes and the absence of these findings on kidney biopsy makes diabetic nephropathy a less likely cause of his ESRD.

B) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is a potential cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. While this condition can be associated with chronic infections (such as hepatitis C) and would result in proteinuria and peripheral edema, amyloidosis classically presents in patients with multiple myeloma and signs of extrarenal organ involvement, such as restrictive cardiomyopathy, as opposed to coronary artery disease. Moreover, renal biopsy in amyloidosis would show green birefringence under Congo red stain.

C) CORRECT:

Hypertensive nephrosclerosis results from renal vascular injury secondary to long-standing arterial hypertension. Sclerosis in the capillary tufts and hyaline arteriolosclerosis, as seen on kidney biopsy, are caused by chronic damage from increased capillary hydrostatic pressure in the glomeruli as well as ischemic damage from progressive narrowing of the renal arterioles. Patients with nephrosclerosis present with elevated blood pressure and laboratory findings that suggest impaired renal function, including elevated BUN and creatinine and presence of proteinuria. Some patients may also have microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Ultrasound typically shows small, atrophic kidneys.

Patients with hypertensive nephrosclerosis initially have microalbuminuria but eventually develop macroalbuminuria as the disease progresses.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. While this condition is associated with hepatitis C and may cause proteinuria and peripheral edema, membranous nephropathy would also cause hypoalbuminemia, and thickening of the glomerular capillary loops and basal membrane would be evident on light microscopy. The absence of these findings in this patient makes membranous nephropathy an unlikely cause of his end-stage renal disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is potential cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Although this condition is associated with hepatitis C and would cause proteinuria and peripheral edema, MPGN would also cause hypoalbuminemia and basement membrane thickening and splitting with IgG or C3 deposits (“train-track” appearance) would be evident on electron microscopy.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a possible cause of chronic kidney disease and secondary hypertension (HTN). Although this patient has multiple risk factors for renal artery stenosis, including HTN, atherosclerotic disease, and diabetes, physical exam findings in renal artery stenosis would include auscultation of a bruit over the flank or abdomen. The absence of an abdominal bruit and the findings from this patient's kidney biopsy suggest his end-stage renal disease is caused by a different mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with peripheral edema, anemia, increased creatinine and BUN, proteinuria, and hyperkalemia. These features are consistent with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of swelling of both feet. The swelling improves slightly with elevation, but her shoes no longer fit. She was diagnosed with hypertension 6 months ago and started treatment with amlodipine. Her average blood pressure over the past several measurements is 136/85 mm Hg. She feels otherwise well. Today, her pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination shows no abnormalities. There is pitting edema of both ankles. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Dihydropyridine CCBs such as amlodipine cause systemic vasodilation, which increases hydrostatic pressure within precapillary blood vessels and can lead to peripheral edema. RAAS inhibitors, such as ACE inhibitors and ARBs lead to vasodilation of postcapillary blood vessels. When used in combination with dihydropyridine CCBs, RAAS inhibitors decrease transcapillary pressure and significantly reduce the risk of developing CCB-related peripheral edema. Moreover, this patient has stage 1 hypertension despite adequate monotherapy, so the addition of a second antihypertensive medication is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Although hydrochlorothiazide is a first-line antihypertensive medication that can be used to treat chronic edema due to congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, and kidney disease, this drug is ineffective for treating peripheral edema caused by calcium channel blockers.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, a loop diuretic, is often used to treat peripheral edema caused by hypervolemic states and can be used to manage hypertension. However, edema caused by CCBs is unrelated to increased plasma volume, and loop diuretics are not effective for treating CCB-related edema. Furosemide is a second-line medication for hypertension that is only preferred for treating individuals with symptomatic heart failure or chronic kidney disease, neither of which this patient has.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of compression stockings and elevation of the lower extremities are among the adjunctive therapies for peripheral edema, regardless of cause. Although compression stockings are useful for treating this patient's edema, another step in management is more appropriate for treating the underlying cause and her persistent stage 1 hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral edema due to vasodilation and increased hydrostatic pressure is the most common adverse effect of dihydropyridine CCBs. However, switching from amlodipine to nifedipine will neither resolve this patient's edema nor treat her persistent stage 1 hypertension.
questions.hint: Peripheral edema is one of the most common adverse effects of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), such as amlodipine. This patient presents with peripheral edema and persistent hypertension.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment because of a blood pressure of 148/98 mm Hg at her last health maintenance examination 4 weeks ago. She feels well. She has a 20-year history of migraine with aura of moderate to severe intensity. For the past year, the frequency of headaches has been increasing, and they now occur 1–2 times per week. Her only medication is sumatriptan. She is sexually active with her husband and uses condoms inconsistently. Her father has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 143/92 mm Hg. A repeat sitting blood pressure 20 minutes later is 145/94 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) can be used as first-line treatment of hypertension, especially in patients with isolated systolic hypertension. However, this patient would benefit more from a medication that can also target her worsening migraine headaches.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) are first-line treatment for hypertension. However, this patient has a history of worsening migraine headaches, for which another antihypertensive is more appropriate. Although lisinopril may be useful for treating migraines, evidence is limited, and this medication should only be considered if first-line agents are not tolerated. Moreover, because ACE inhibitors are teratogenic, they should generally be avoided in patients who use contraception inconsistently and wish to become pregnant in the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa is an alpha-2 receptor agonist most often used to manage hypertensive disorders in pregnancy and, rarely, as a second-line treatment for hypertension. Another medication is more appropriate for this patient's worsening migraines.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with both hypertension and a history of migraine requiring prophylactic therapy, beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are an adequate first-line alternative as they target both conditions. In patients with hypertension and no other comorbidities, thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitor, calcium channel blockers, and/or angiotensin-receptor blockers should be tried first, before administering a beta blocker.

See “Antihypertensive treatment by comorbidities” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-receptor blockers (e.g., losartan) can be used as first-line treatment for hypertension. However, this patient with a history of worsening migraine headaches would benefit more from an alternative antihypertensive that can treat both of her medical problems. Moreover, ARB should be avoided in female patients of reproductive age that are sexually active, as they are known to be teratogenic.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertension and a history of increasingly frequent migraine headaches, making a specific medication more appropriate in this case.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, her blood pressure was 154/78 mm Hg at a routine visit. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 14 have been: 156/76 mm Hg, 158/80 mm Hg, and 160/80 mm Hg. She has trouble falling asleep but otherwise feels well. She had a cold that resolved with over-the-counter medication 2 weeks ago. She has a history of primary hypothyroidism and a cyst in the right kidney, which was found incidentally 20 years ago. She takes levothyroxine. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Her pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 162/79 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's blood pressure findings?

choices.text: Decrease in renal artery blood flow

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased kidney size is seen in patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and is associated with both decrease in GFR and the development of hypertension. Virtually all patients with ADPKD will develop hypertension. However, it is typically not associated with isolated systolic hypertension. This patient has an isolated cyst that is most likely benign and clinically inconsequential.

B) CORRECT:

Isolated systolic hypertension is caused by decreased arterial elasticity and compliance associated with aging. This condition most commonly occurs in adults aged over 60 years and typically manifests with wide pulse pressure. Patients with isolated systolic hypertension have a high risk of renal dysfunction and cardiovascular events, e.g., myocardial infarction, stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common cause of secondary hypertension. Nocturnal periods of hypoxemia and hypercapnia activate the sympathetic nervous system and trigger surges in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. This patient has no risk factors for OSA (e.g., obesity, smoking, alcohol consumption before sleep), nor does she present with symptoms of this diagnosis (apnea, breathlessness or choking in her sleep, chronic fatigue). The isolated elevation in systolic blood pressure also makes this etiology unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Most over-the-counter nasal decongestants contain sympathomimetics (e.g., phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine), which induce both local and systemic vasoconstriction. While the use of these medications can cause hypertension, the time course of this patient's presentation and her isolated systolic pressures make this etiology unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Increase in end-diastolic volume, as seen in aortic regurgitation (AR), causes increased stroke volume and increases the pulse pressure. While this patient does have evidence of a widened pulse pressure, AR alone would not cause hypertension, and a high-pitched, early diastolic murmur would be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

An increase in cardiac output secondary to hyperthyroidism (including from excessive levothyroxine) could present with hypertension. However, her recent thyroid studies were normal and she has no other evidence of active thyroid disease.

G) INCORRECT:

Reduced renal artery blood flow would cause activation of the renin-angiotensin system and result in renovascular hypertension. Important causes of reduced renal artery blood flow include renal artery stenosis, external compression of the renal arteries (cyst, tumor, etc), atherosclerosis of the renal arteries, and fibromuscular dysplasia. While atherosclerosis of the renal arteries should be considered given her age, the normal diastolic pressures in this patient make another underlying cause more likely.

H) INCORRECT:

A decrease in baroreceptor sensitivity describes the underlying mechanism that results in orthostatic hypotension. Unlike this patient's asymptomatic hypertension, it is characterized by autonomic dysfunction and insufficient counterregulation after postural changes that leads to dizziness and syncope after standing up.

I) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is the most common cause of secondary hypertension and typically presents with hypertension and hypokalemia. The blood pressure seen in primary hyperaldosteronism is frequently markedly elevated, and causes increases in both systolic and diastolic pressures. This woman's isolated systolic hypertension and normal lab values make an alternative etiology more likely.
questions.hint: This older patient has a wide pulse pressure with elevated systolic blood pressure and normal diastolic pressure.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He feels well. He was diagnosed with hypertension 3 months ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 4 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol on the weekends. He walks for 45 minutes daily and eats three meals per day. His current diet consists mostly of canned tuna and cured meats. He started eating whole-wheat bread after he was diagnosed with hypertension. He drinks 1 to 2 cups of coffee daily. His mother has a history of hyperthyroidism. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and a multivitamin pill every night before sleeping. His wife told him that he sometimes snores at night, but he reports that he usually sleeps well and feels refreshed in the mornings. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While increasing the patient's dose of hydrochlorothiazide may be an option, other measures should be considered first before changing his pharmacological regimen.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, such as metoprolol, are usually not recommended for the initial pharmacotherapy of hypertension because other agents are more effective. Beta blockers are typically only added to the medication regimen if monotherapy with a thiazide diuretic, calcium channel blocker, ACE inhibitor, or angiotensin-receptor blocker is unable to control blood pressure. Despite showing an inadequate response to his single anti-hypertensive medication, this patient has not exhausted all initial management strategies. Moreover, the combination of beta blockers and thiazide diuretics is associated with an increased risk of synergistic adverse metabolic effects (impaired glucose tolerance, dyslipidemia).

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism should always be considered when evaluating a patient with secondary hypertension. While this patient has a family history of thyroid disease, he has no other clinical features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, diaphoresis, diarrhea, etc) and does not meet the criteria for therapy-resistant hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Daily aerobic exercise should always be recommended in patients diagnosed with hypertension as part of lifestyle modification counseling. However, this patient already walks 45 minutes per day, so an additional exercise routine is unlikely to provide much benefit.

E) CORRECT:

Lifestyle modification counseling should always be performed when evaluating a patient with hypertension. Emphasis should be made on addressing modifiable risk factors (diet, exercise, weight loss, smoking cessation); although this patient's daily exercise and whole-grain bread intake are commendable, his high-sodium diet (i.e., canned foods and cured meats) likely contributes to his hypertension and should be modified appropriately. This patient should be encouraged to follow a DASH diet, which is proven to reduce blood pressure compared to average American diet or salt-restricted diet alone.

See “Lifestyle changes for managing hypertension” table.

F) INCORRECT:

Polysomnography is a test that is used to detect potential obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a common cause of secondary hypertension. Although this patient snores at night, he does not have any other history or exam findings to suggest OSA (e.g., daytime sleepiness, apneic spells at night, morning headaches, etc), and he reports that he sleeps well.
questions.hint: Despite therapy with an antihypertensive drug, this patient continues to have elevated blood pressure.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She had a blood pressure recording of 148/94 mm Hg on her previous visit five weeks ago. Her home blood pressure log shows readings of 151/97 and 146/92 mm Hg in the past week. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, lipids, TSH, and fasting glucose are within the reference range. A urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Since hypertension is an asymptomatic and insidious disease with several complications, patients should be evaluated for end-organ damage once the diagnosis has been established. Electrocardiogram (ECG) should be done in all newly diagnosed hypertensive patients to look for early electrical changes associated with hypertensive heart disease (e.g., left ventricular hypertrophy, left atrial enlargement) or concomitant heart disease (e.g., coronary artery disease, arrhythmias).

Besides an ECG, the initial evaluation of newly diagnosed hypertension should include a complete blood cell count, fasting serum glucose, lipid profile, TSH levels, serum electrolytes, renal function tests (creatinine with eGFR), and urinalysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Checking plasma renin activity would be appropriate if Conn syndrome were suspected as a cause of secondary hypertension. However, Conn syndrome is unlikely in a patient with a normal level of serum K+.

C) INCORRECT:

Since hypertension is an asymptomatic and insidious disease with several complications, an evaluation should be performed to assess the extent of end-organ damage once the diagnosis has been established. It would be inappropriate to perform no further testing in this newly diagnosed hypertensive patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is not routinely recommended in newly diagnosed hypertensive patients unless there are features of heart failure or there is suspicion of left ventricular dysfunction or coronary artery disease. This patient is asymptomatic with no signs of heart failure on physical examination, which means that another method of evaluation should be used.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasonography should be performed in individuals with newly diagnosed hypertension when renal disease is suspected as the underlying cause of hypertension (i.e., renovascular hypertension). Renovascular hypertension is unlikely in a patient with normal urinalysis, normal serum creatinine level, and normal abdominal physical examination (i.e., no abdominal bruit, no abdominal or flank pain).

F) INCORRECT:

Checking plasma metanephrine levels would be appropriate if pheochromocytoma were suspected. Patients with pheochromocytoma usually present with episodic blood pressure crises accompanied by diaphoresis, palpitations, or pallor. This patient has consistently elevated blood pressure on multiple visits with no symptoms of episodic catecholamine surge (diaphoresis, palpitations, pallor).
questions.hint: This patient has newly diagnosed hypertension and should undergo the basic workup to evaluate for end-organ damage and assess for cardiovascular risk. One routine test has not yet been conducted.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of 24-hour blood pressure monitoring results. Over the last 3 months, she has had intermittent nausea, decreased appetite, and increasing weakness and fatigue during the day. She has been treated twice for kidney stones within the past year. Her current medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, and furosemide. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 97 kg (214 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 152/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Na+

141 mEq/L


Cl−

101 mEq/L


K+

4.5 mEq/L


HCO3−

24 mEq/L


Calcium
12.9 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


A 24-hour blood pressure monitoring indicates elevated nocturnal blood pressure. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum aldosterone-to-renin ratio indicates primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome). Primary hyperaldosteronism can cause secondary hypertension with features of hypokalemia (e.g., fatigue and muscle weakness). However, this patient's potassium level is normal. Moreover, hypercalcemia and symptoms such as recurrent renal stones or gastrointestinal complaints are not expected in Conn syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol is diagnostic of Cushing syndrome (hypercortisolism), which can cause treatment-resistant secondary hypertension with lethargy and muscle weakness. However, it typically also manifests with central obesity, thin and easily bruisable skin, abdominal striae, and proximal muscle atrophy.

C) CORRECT:

Increased serum parathyroid hormone is characteristic of primary hyperparathyroidism, a known cause of secondary hypertension. Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have hypercalcemia and can present with recurrent nephrolithiasis, nausea, decreased appetite, fatigue, and weakness. Hypercalcemia is thought to cause hypertension by affecting vascular reactivity and interrupting day-night blood pressure regulation.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is also a common finding in MEN 1 and MEN 2A. MEN 2A often also involves pheochromocytoma, another possible (concurrent) cause of secondary hypertension that should be considered in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) would indicate hyperthyroidism, which is an important cause of treatment-resistant secondary hypertension and may present with weakness and fatigue. Hyperthyroidism could also explain this patient's hypercalcemia, as thyroid hormones have osteoclastic activity. However, decreased appetite is not typical of hyperthyroidism, and this patient is lacking other symptoms that are expected in the setting of thyroid hormone excess (e.g., heat intolerance, weight loss, diarrhea, tachycardia, tremor).

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased renal blood flow due to renal artery stenosis or fibromuscular dysplasia is a common cause of treatment-resistant secondary hypertension, which is often accompanied by fatigue and weakness. Decreased perfusion triggers the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and causes persistent vasoconstriction as well as volume retention. However, renal artery stenosis does not explain this patient's hypercalcemia or recurrent kidney stones. Furthermore, constantly elevated aldosterone would lead to hypokalemia, which this patient does not have.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased nocturnal oxygen saturation is characteristic of patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which can cause secondary hypertension and excessive daytime fatigue. However, OSA does not explain this patient's hypercalcemia, recurrent kidney stones, nausea, or decreased appetite.
questions.hint: This patient has resistant hypertension despite treatment with three antihypertensive drugs, which should raise concern for secondary hypertension. She also has nephrolithiasis, nausea and decreased appetite, fatigue, and weakness.

questions.text: Three days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old woman with resistant hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the doctor because of decreased urination. She denies dysuria, fevers, or chills. Blood pressure is 133/67 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Compared to measurements from one week ago, the glomerular filtration rate is markedly decreased and plasma renin activity is elevated. A duplex ultrasound of the kidneys shows increased systolic flow velocity in both renal arteries when compared to the aorta. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's worsening renal function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the ascending loop of Henle. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not augment the activity of renin.

B) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone acts on the distal convoluted tubules. It does not directly reduce glomerular filtration rate or increase the activity of renin.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that acts on the proximal portion of the distal convoluted tubules. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not increase the activity of renin.

D) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors like enalapril inhibit efferent arteriole constriction, which can lead to a decrease in the GFR and acute kidney injury, as seen here. Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis are especially susceptible to this effect, as the kidneys rely on efferent arteriole constriction to maintain the GFR. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) work in a similar fashion. Therefore, both ARBs and ACEIs are relatively contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a selective beta blocker that is used to treat hypertension. Beta blockers do not exhibit a marked effect on glomerular filtration rate and should decrease, not increase, renin activity at normal doses.
questions.hint: This patient's duplex ultrasound shows findings consistent with renal artery stenosis, which manifests with increased flow velocity from the narrowed artery.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with coronary artery disease and hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure ranged from 160/100 mm Hg to 150/94 mm Hg on his previous 3 visits over the past 4 months. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and metoprolol. Three weeks ago, he was also started on amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 158/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Renal duplex ultrasonography shows 90% occlusion of the right renal artery. Decreased renal blood flow is most likely to cause which of the following?

choices.text: Mesangial expansion and glomerular basement membrane thickening
Decreased prostaglandin synthesis by macula densa
Decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate at proximal tubule

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This elderly man has treatment-resistant hypertension and radiological evidence of significant (> 60%) renal artery stenosis (RAS), which indicates renovascular hypertension. RAS causes renal hypoperfusion. The juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) detects the decreased perfusion pressure at the afferent arteriole and secretes renin in an attempt to restore renal perfusion (tubuloglomerular feedback). Renin activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which results in vasoconstriction and hypertension. Prolonged renal hypoperfusion and stimulation of the JGA due to renal artery stenosis cause cellular hyperplasia of the JGA. Other causes of JGA hyperplasia include cardiac failure (which causes renal hypoperfusion), angiotensin receptor blocker therapy (loss of negative feedback for renin secretion by angiotensin II), chronic salt loss (e.g., Addison disease), and Bartter syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal hypoperfusion activates the RAAS by stimulating renin secretion. This increases serum levels of angiotensin II, which increases arterial and venous vasoconstriction (not vasodilation) to maintain renal perfusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesangial expansion (on light microscopy) and glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening (on electron microscopy) are pathognomonic features of diabetic nephropathy. Chronic hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia stimulate collagen and glycoprotein synthesis within the GBM and mesangial matrix (protein glycosylation). In advanced disease, the progressive growth of the mesangial matrix and GBM thickening lead to nodular glomerulosclerosis, which is characterized by Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules within glomeruli. These findings are not caused by decreased renal perfusion.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain; high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus can be seen (dashed outline), featuring a thickened glomerular basement membrane and containing abundant pink, hyaline depositions of PAS-positive material (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules or nodular glomerulosclerosis; examples indicated by yellow overlay). Various tubules and vessels surround the glomerulus. An arteriole with distinct hyaline deposits is located above the glomerulus (hyaline arteriolosclerosis; blue overlay).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis combined with hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a typical feature seen in diabetic glomerulopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

The macula densa detects Na+ levels in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). Renal hypoperfusion decreases Na+ levels in the DCT, which stimulates (not decreases) COX-2-mediated prostaglandin secretion from the macula densa. The prostaglandins stimulate renin secretion, which results in activation of the RAAS in an attempt to restore renal perfusion (tubuloglomerular feedback) and therefore hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal hypoperfusion activates the RAAS by stimulating renin secretion. This increases serum levels of angiotensin II, which activates the Na+/H+ exchanger in the proximal tubule. This stimulates (not decreases) Na+ reabsorption, H+ excretion, and, indirectly, bicarbonate reabsorption.
questions.hint: Renal artery stenosis decreases renal perfusion and leads to compensatory activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

questions.text: A 65-year-old African American man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment 4 weeks after elevated blood pressure readings at his last visit, which were confirmed with ambulatory monitoring. His measurements averaged 150/95 mm Hg. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. His pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a regular rhythm with no murmurs. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum glucose, electrolytes, and creatinine, are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. In addition to lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with thiazide diuretics, such as chlorthalidone, is a suitable treatment option for patients with stage 1 hypertension or isolated systolic hypertension, especially when no significant comorbidities are present. However, this patient has stage 2 hypertension, for which monotherapy is not appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Combining ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) with ARBs (e.g., losartan) does not improve blood pressure control or cardiovascular outcomes. Furthermore, both drugs inhibit the renin-angiotensin system, and combining them elevates the risk of hypotension, hyperkalemia, and renal dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol is a second-line therapy for hypertension that is typically used in patients with cardiovascular comorbidities such as ischemic heart disease, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. Metoprolol is not appropriate as a first-line therapy for isolated hypertension in any patient group.

D) CORRECT:

Adults with stage 2 hypertension and an average blood pressure > 20/10 mm Hg above target should be advised on lifestyle changes and started on combination therapy with two first-line antihypertensives. Common combinations include an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) or an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) such as losartan, paired with either a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB) or a thiazide-type diuretic such as chlorthalidone. Patients starting pharmacological therapy should have a follow-up visit within one month to assess blood pressure response and medication tolerance. Once the condition is controlled, follow-up should occur every 3–6 months and then annually if blood pressure remains stable.

Previous guidelines recommended the sole use of either thiazide-type diuretics or CCBs for treating hypertension in Black patients without chronic kidney disease. These recommendations were based on the incorrect assumption that Black individuals have increased salt sensitivity and low renin levels and are therefore particularly responsive to diuretics. Because of this approach, Black patients were less likely to receive renin-angiotensin-aldosterone inhibitors, potentially limiting access to their cardioprotective and renoprotective benefits. The current consensus is that a patient's race or ethnicity should not be the basis for excluding any major antihypertensive class in combination regimens.

E) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with an ACE inhibitor such as ramipril is recommended for patients with stage 1 hypertension, especially for those with diabetes mellitus and albuminuria or renal disease, as these drugs are nephroprotective. However, this patient has stage 2 hypertension, for which monotherapy is not appropriate at this time.
questions.hint: This patient meets the diagnostic criteria for stage 2 hypertension (i.e., SBP ≥ 140 mm Hg or DBP ≥ 90 mm Hg) and has an average blood pressure > 20/10 mm Hg above target.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and asthma comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent dry, hacking cough. He does not have fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He does not smoke cigarettes. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, albuterol, and ramipril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Start dextromethorphan and increase frequency of albuterol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dextromethorphan is an NMDA glutamate receptor antagonist used as an over-the-counter cough suppressant and albuterol is a beta-2 agonist used in the treatment of asthma. While dextromethorphan might temporarily mitigate this patient's cough, it would not address the root cause of it. Additionally, there is no other evidence that this patient's cough is associated with an asthma exacerbation (such as dyspnea, wheezing, or chest tightness); increasing albuterol is therefore unlikely to resolve this problem.

B) INCORRECT:

Both simvastatin and atorvastatin are statins, which are indicated to treat hyperlipidemia and act by decreasing LDL levels. Classic side effects of statins include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis but not cough. Therefore, changing the patient's medication from simvastatin to atorvastatin would be unlikely to resolve his cough.

C) CORRECT:

Dry cough is a characteristic side effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Inhibition of ACE also causes an increase in bradykinin, which can lead to bronchoconstriction and dry cough. If cough caused by ACE inhibitors is present, discontinuation of ACE inhibitors and switching to angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) such as candesartan is recommended. Cough is a rare adverse effect of ARBs, as these agents do not influence the breakdown of kinins.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include hypotension, hyperkalemia, a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and angioedema.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

D) INCORRECT:

Ramipril and lisinopril are both angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). A common side effect of treatment with ACE inhibitors is an intermittent, nonproductive cough, such as the one seen in this patient. Because all ACE inhibitors are known to cause this cough, switching from one agent to another within this class would be unlikely to resolve the problem.

E) INCORRECT:

Albuterol and salmeterol are both beta-2 adrenergic agonists used in the treatment of asthma. While albuterol is a short-acting agent used for acute asthma exacerbations, salmeterol is a long-acting agent used for prophylaxis of asthma attacks. Although this patient has a history of asthma, his current cough seems unrelated to it. He does not have a history or findings to suggest exacerbation of asthma (e.g., exposure to triggers, dyspnea, or tachypnea on examination). Moreover, stopping albuterol would not be appropriate if there was any suspicion of an asthma exacerbation.
questions.hint: Increased local concentrations of bradykinin and substance P are thought to be responsible for the symptom this patient is experiencing.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, his blood pressure was 160/80 mm Hg. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 15 found: 165/75 mm Hg, 162/82 mm Hg, and 170/80 mm Hg, respectively. He had a cold that was treated with over-the-counter medication 4 weeks ago. Pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 165/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's elevated blood pressure?

choices.text: Increase in left ventricular end-diastolic volume

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A decrease in renal artery blood flow would activate the renin-angiotensin system and result in renovascular hypertension. Important causes of reduced renal artery blood flow include renal artery stenosis, external compression of the renal arteries (e.g., by a tumor or cyst), atherosclerosis of the renal arteries, and fibromuscular dysplasia. While atherosclerosis of the renal arteries should be considered given the patient's age, his normal diastolic pressures make another underlying cause more likely. Furthermore, only bilateral renal artery disease resulting in a significant decrease in GFR would manifest with hypertension; this patient's normal creatinine makes such a decrease unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

A decrease in arterial compliance secondary to age-related reduction in arterial elasticity and increased stiffness is common in individuals > 60 years old. This decrease results in isolated systolic hypertension, which is characterized by a wide pulse pressure, as seen in this patient. Treatment with an antihypertensive agent, such as a thiazide diuretic or calcium channel blocker, should be initiated to decrease the risk of a cardiovascular event (e.g., myocardial infarction, stroke, or renal dysfunction).

C) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is the most common cause of secondary hypertension and classically manifests with resistant hypertension and hypokalemia. The blood pressure seen in primary hyperaldosteronism is often markedly elevated and causes increases in both systolic and diastolic pressures. This patient's isolated systolic hypertension and normal lab values make this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated LV end-diastolic volume, as seen in aortic regurgitation (AR), increases stroke volume and can also widen pulse pressure. However, AR alone would not cause this patient's hypertension, and a high-pitched, early diastolic murmur would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

A decrease in baroreceptor sensitivity is the underlying mechanism of orthostatic hypotension. Unlike this patient's asymptomatic hypertension, it is characterized by autonomic dysfunction and insufficient counter-regulation after postural changes that leads to dizziness and syncope after standing up.

F) INCORRECT:

Most over-the-counter nasal decongestants contain sympathomimetics (e.g., phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine), which induce both local and systemic vasoconstriction. While these medications can cause hypertension, the time course of this patient's presentation and his isolated systolic pressures make a medication-induced etiology unlikely.
questions.hint: This elderly patient has a wide pulse pressure with elevated systolic blood pressure readings and normal diastolic pressures.

questions.text: A 23-year-old African American woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has no history of serious illness and her previous health maintenance examination was within normal limits. She is sexually active with one male partner. Her father has type 2 diabetes mellitus and her mother has hypertension. She does not smoke and drinks alcohol socially. She takes a multivitamin daily. She is 188 cm (6 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 158/89 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After a 5-minute rest, her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has elevated blood pressure readings obtained on a single visit. Remeasuring blood pressure on both arms in 2 weeks is the most appropriate next step to determine if she has hypertension. Hypertension is typically only diagnosed if the average blood pressure of at least two readings from at least two separate visits is elevated or if the average blood pressure recorded on home or ambulatory blood pressure monitoring is elevated. There are two exceptions where hypertension can be diagnosed with a single elevated blood pressure reading, including a single reading of ≥ 180/≥ 120 mm Hg or ≥ 160/≥ 100 mm Hg with known end-organ damage (e.g., myocardial ischemia, kidney injury, hypertensive retinopathy).

Patients should be counseled on the importance of lifestyle modifications (e.g., weight loss, DASH diet, decreasing dietary sodium and alcohol, exercise, and increasing dietary potassium) at the first detection of elevated blood pressure. Individuals with newly diagnosed hypertension should then have the following basic testing to evaluate for potential end-organ damage, further cardiovascular risk factors, and potential causes of secondary hypertension: ECG, CBC, basic metabolic panel, lipid profile, TSH, and urinalysis (to assess for microscopic hematuria and urine protein/creatinine ratio). Because this patient is < 30 years of age, secondary causes of hypertension should be suspected and ruled out.

B) INCORRECT:

An ECG should be obtained in all patients with newly diagnosed hypertension. However, as this patient does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension, an ECG is premature at this stage.

An ECG should also be obtained in all patients who present with hypertensive crisis for two reasons: (1) to look for signs of myocardial ischemia, which is a feature of hypertensive emergency requiring ICU admission and the immediate initiation of IV antihypertensive therapy; and (2) because a single blood pressure reading of ≥ 180/≥ 120 mm Hg or ≥ 160/≥ 100 mm Hg with known end-organ damage (e.g., myocardial ischemia, kidney injury, hypertensive retinopathy) meets the criteria for a diagnosis of hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

An echocardiography with Doppler is used to diagnose coarctation of the aorta, which is a cause of secondary hypertension. Secondary causes should always be suspected and ruled out, especially in individuals < 30 years or > 55 years with new-onset hypertension. However, as this patient does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension, it is premature to conduct a workup for secondary hypertension at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

A thiazide diuretic is an appropriate first-line antihypertensive medication that can be used in combination with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker for individuals diagnosed with stage 2 hypertension. Although this patient has a blood pressure of 155/85 mm Hg, she does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension. Therefore, it is premature to initiate pharmacological treatment at this time.

Previous guidelines recommended the sole use of either thiazide-type diuretics or calcium channel blockers for treating hypertension in Black patients without chronic kidney disease. These recommendations were based on the incorrect assumption that Black individuals have increased salt sensitivity and low renin levels and are therefore particularly responsive to diuretics. Because of this approach, Black patients were less likely to receive renin-angiotensin-aldosterone inhibitors, potentially limiting access to their cardioprotective and renoprotective benefits. The current consensus is that a patient's race or ethnicity should not be the basis for excluding any major antihypertensive class in combination regimens.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal Doppler ultrasonography (alternatively CT angiography) can be used to diagnose renal fibromuscular dysplasia, which is a cause of secondary hypertension. Secondary causes should always be suspected and ruled out, especially in individuals < 30 years or > 55 years with new-onset hypertension. In particular, an elevated blood pressure in a young woman may raise suspicion for fibromuscular dysplasia. However, as this patient does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension, it is premature to conduct a workup for secondary hypertension at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor is an appropriate first-line treatment for individuals with newly diagnosed stage 1 hypertension. Although this patient has a blood pressure of 155/85 mm Hg, she does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension. Therefore, it is premature to initiate pharmacological treatment at this time.

G) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications such as weight loss (in overweight patients), DASH diet, exercise, a low-sodium (not low-potassium) diet, reducing alcohol intake, and smoking cessation (in order of decreasing effectiveness) are helpful in preventing hypertension and managing milder forms of hypertension, and they should be recommended to all individuals with an elevated blood pressure ≥ 120/80 mm Hg. This patient should therefore be counseled on lifestyle modifications, which includes recommending a low-sodium diet.
questions.hint: This healthy patient presents with elevated blood pressure on routine examination, raising concern for hypertension, which requires an additional diagnostic step.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of headaches and frequent episodes of bleeding from her nose. Over the past 2 months, she has had shortness of breath and intermittent leg pain while jogging. She has no history of previous illnesses. Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 52 years. She smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally used methamphetamines and cocaine during college, but she has not used illicit drugs for the past 5 years. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 168/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased femoral pulses compared to the brachial pulses. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.2 g/dL


Serum



 Na+

142 mEq/L


 K+

3.6 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


An ECG shows prominent R waves in leads V5 and V6 and deep S waves in leads V1 and V2. An x-ray of the chest shows enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and erosions of the inferior aspects of the 4th through 8th ribs bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is a diagnostic and/or therapeutic procedure for several cardiac conditions, including coarctation of the aorta, which this patient has. However, cardiac catheterization is an invasive procedure and is more typically reserved for cases in which a concurrent intervention is expected or evaluation for concurrent coronary artery disease is needed.

B) INCORRECT:

The ankle-brachial index would be decreased in patients with arterial insufficiency of the lower extremities but the ankle-brachial index cannot be used to determine the underlying cause of arterial insufficiency. A different diagnostic step is necessary to establish the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal duplex ultrasonography is the imaging test of choice for evaluating renal artery stenosis. Although this patient's secondary hypertension is also due to a vascular source, she does not have an abdominal bruit or hypokalemia (secondary to release of renin) that are characteristic of renal artery stenosis. Moreover, renal artery stenosis does not explain her x-ray finding of rib notching.

D) CORRECT:

Doppler echocardiography is the test of choice for diagnosing aortic coarctation. In addition to echocardiography, which provides dynamic imaging of the heart and can detect concurrent anomalies, Doppler helps to localize the coarctation and estimate its severity. This patient's clinical features such as features of arterial insufficiency in the lower extremities (e.g., intermittent claudication during physical activity, decreased femoral pulses), features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headache, epistaxis), and evidence of collateral circulation (rib notching on x-ray) are consistent with the presentation of aortic coarctation in adulthood. Moreover, this patient is now experiencing sequelae of untreated aortic coarctation such as left ventricular hypertrophy (as evidenced by her ECG findings) due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction and dyspnea due to heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of metanephrines in 24-hour urine is the confirmatory test of choice for pheochromocytoma. Hypertension and headaches in a young patient may be consistent with pheochromocytoma, but this type of tumor does not explain this patient's lower extremity claudication with exertion and rib notching on x-ray. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of pheochromocytoma, including paroxysmal diaphoresis and palpitations.

F) INCORRECT:

Urine toxicology screening for cocaine can help in the assessment for an alternative cause of secondary hypertension, headaches, epistaxis, and heart failure. However, cocaine use would not explain this patient's lower extremity claudication with exertion and rib notching seen on x-ray.

G) INCORRECT:

Monitoring of 24-hour blood pressure can be used to diagnose hypertension. While this patient is hypertensive, blood pressure monitoring would not help identify the underlying etiology of this patient's secondary hypertension. She has a constellation of clinical features, including lower extremity claudication with exertion, rib notching on x-ray, and heart failure at a young age, that would be difficult to explain by isolated hypertension.
questions.hint: This disease is also often seen in individuals with Takayasu arteritis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man returns to the office for a follow-up appointment 1 week after he was evaluated for high blood pressure. He works as an investment banker. He says, “I am married to my work” and does not have time for regular physical activity. He mostly orders take-out and fast food. He does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. He drinks two to three 12-oz beers daily. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is 186 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 143/87 mm Hg in the right arm and 140/90 mm Hg in the left arm. The patient says that he wants to avoid medication and asks which single lifestyle modification would most effectively lower his blood pressure. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: “Lifestyle modifications without pharmacotherapy cannot sufficiently reduce high blood pressure”
"Losing approximately 10% of your current body weight would be the most effective measure"
"Reducing your alcohol consumption to a maximum of one drink per day would be the most effective measure"
"Reducing your sodium intake to less than 1500 mg per day would be the most effective measure"
“Adopting a DASH diet would be the most effective measure”
"Walking for 30 minutes, 5 days a week would be the most effective measure"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonpharmacological measures (i.e., lifestyle changes) should be pursued in every patient with a systolic blood pressure > 130 mm Hg or a diastolic blood pressure > 90 mm Hg and have been shown to effectively reduce blood pressure. Lifestyle modifications can be initiated with or without pharmacotherapy, as not all patients with high blood pressure require antihypertensive drugs right away. The decision of whether to initiate pharmacological treatment depends on the patient's blood pressure, comorbidities, and preference. This patient wishes to avoid pharmacological therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Weight loss is an effective way to reduce blood pressure in overweight and obese patients. Systolic blood pressure is thought to rise in obesity because of peripheral insulin resistance, which results in hyperinsulinemia, triggering increased reabsorption of sodium and fluid. Approximately 1 mm Hg reduction in systolic blood pressure is expected for every 1 kg of weight loss. This patient, however, has a normal body weight and would most likely benefit from a different lifestyle modification at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreasing alcohol consumption to a maximum of one drink per day is a healthy lifestyle modification that should be encouraged in all patients. However, moderating alcohol consumption has only been shown to lead to a reduction in systolic blood pressure of up to 4 mm Hg. There are other lifestyle modifications that can result in a more significant reduction.

D) INCORRECT:

Reducing sodium intake to less than 1500 mg per day has been shown to reduce systolic blood pressure by approximately 5–6 mm Hg and could be offered as complementary lifestyle modification. Additionally, a low-sodium diet improves vascular structure and function and may help reduce the risk of gastric cancer, nephrolithiasis, and osteoporosis. However, there are other lifestyle modifications that can result in a more significant reduction of systolic blood pressure.

E) CORRECT:

All patients with newly diagnosed hypertension should implement lifestyle modifications to reduce their blood pressure. The DASH diet has been shown to reduce systolic blood pressure by approximately 11 mm Hg and should be recommended to all patients with hypertension who do not have a balanced diet. The DASH diet has also been shown to reduce levels of LDL cholesterol, which leads to improved cardiovascular health.

See the “Lifestyle changes for managing hypertension” table.

F) INCORRECT:

Walking for 30 minutes, 5 days per week has been shown to successfully reduce systolic blood pressure by approximately 5–8 mm Hg, and could be offered to this patient as a complementary therapy. Regular aerobic exercise also has additional health benefits, including the potential to reduce total cholesterol and raise HDL cholesterol as well as reduce mortality due to cardiovascular disease. However, there are other lifestyle modifications that can result in a more significant reduction of systolic blood pressure.

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s elevated blood pressure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although hyperthyroidism can cause hypertension and tremor, other expected findings such as weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, and increased bowel movements are not present. Furthermore, physical examination of the thyroid did not reveal any pathologies (e.g., goiter, nodules, or tenderness), making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Cigarette smoking is a modifiable risk factor for hypertension. However, this patient has been smoking for 2 years and had normal blood pressure at his visit 6 months ago.

C) CORRECT:

Excessive alcohol intake can cause elevated blood pressure. Because this patient's blood pressure was normal at his last visit 6 months ago and has become elevated since he began drinking heavily 4 months ago, excessive alcohol intake is the most likely cause.

Other modifiable risk factors for hypertension include obesity, diabetes, smoking, high sodium diet, physical inactivity, and psychological stress.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) can cause secondary hypertension as a result of renal artery stenosis. However, this patient has none of the other typical features of renal artery stenosis, such as abdominal bruit, flank or abdominal pain, and symptoms of chronic kidney disease (e.g., pulmonary and/or peripheral edema, uremia).

E) INCORRECT:

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney (ADPKD) disease can cause hypertension due to increased renin production. However, this patient has none of the other associated findings, such as signs of chronic kidney disease (e.g., pulmonary and/or peripheral edema, uremia) as well as flank or abdominal pain, nephrolithiasis, recurrent urinary infections, gross hematuria, and proteinuria. Additionally, the patient has no family history of kidney disease, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) typically manifests with more severe symptoms than ADPKD. For example, even a mild case of ARPKD can cause cirrhosis in adolescent patients.
questions.hint: Remember that this patient's vital signs were normal at the last visit 6 months ago.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks' gestation comes to the office for her first prenatal visit. She feels well, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 147/94 mm Hg on both arms. Physical examination shows bilateral breast tenderness. The uterus is consistent in size with 6–8 weeks' gestation. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and creatinine, are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Repeat blood pressure 6 hours later is 144/89 mm Hg in the right arm and 141/86 mm Hg in the left arm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: No pharmacotherapy is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) are a first-line medication for the treatment of hypertension in nonpregnant patients. During pregnancy, however, ACE inhibitors are teratogenic, possibly resulting in cardiovascular and central nervous system malformations in the first trimester and causing oligohydramnios, renal hypoplasia, and impaired cranial ossification when administered in the second and third trimesters.

B) CORRECT:

Methyldopa is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that is safe for use in pregnancy. Mild chronic hypertension in pregnancy is defined as blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg but < 160/90 mm Hg and should be treated with oral agents to reduce the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Other oral antihypertensives indicated in pregnancy include oral nifedipine, labetalol, or hydralazine. Patients with severe hypertension (i.e., systolic blood pressure ≥ 160 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 110 mm Hg lasting ≥ 15 minutes) require urgent blood pressure control with parenteral labetalol, parenteral hydralazine, or nifedipine.

See “Overview of antihypertensives to avoid during pregnancy” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) are a first-line medication for the treatment of hypertension in nonpregnant patients. Thiazide diuretics are not associated with teratogenicity and may be used in pregnant patients with volume overload (e.g., heart failure) or if other agents fail to reduce blood pressure. They are not, however, recommended as first-line therapy during pregnancy because they decrease plasma volume, which may result in a reduction of placental perfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Previously, pharmacotherapy was reserved for patients with severe chronic hypertension in pregnancy (i.e., blood pressure ≥ 160/110 mm Hg). However, according to recent data, the threshold to initiate antihypertensives in treatment-naive patients is a blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg. Therefore, pharmacotherapy is recommended for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., atenolol) are not a recommended first-line therapy for hypertension. During pregnancy, beta blockers are safe to use, but atenolol is contraindicated because it causes intrauterine growth restriction and impairs placental growth. Preferred beta blockers during pregnancy include labetalol and metoprolol.
questions.hint: Chronic hypertension can be diagnosed in nonpregnant patients and in pregnant patients during the first 20 weeks of pregnancy if they present with systolic blood pressure ≥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg on two separate measurements at least 4 hours apart.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Four weeks ago, she was seen on a health maintenance visit where increased blood pressure readings of 141/90 mm Hg on both arms were observed. She reports a blood pressure reading of 125/80 mmHg that she measured with a neighbor's home blood pressure monitor 1 week ago. The patient sleeps well and has no history of headaches, palpitations, or epistaxis. She is physically active and walks her dog for 45 minutes every day. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease for which she takes pantoprazole. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141.1 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg on the right arm and 143/91 mm Hg on the left arm. Blood pressure measured 10 minutes later is 140/92 mm Hg on the right arm and 141/89 mm Hg on the left arm. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Combination therapy with lisinopril and amlodipine
Reassurance and follow-up at the office in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies, including a serum electrolyte panel, should be obtained in all patients with newly diagnosed hypertension. This patient has suspected hypertension based on elevated in-office blood pressure readings; however, the diagnosis must be confirmed before obtaining laboratory testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography can detect renal artery stenosis, which is a common cause of secondary hypertension. However, evaluation for secondary causes is only recommended in patients with findings that suggest secondary hypertension (e.g., severe or resistant hypertension, hypertension associated with electrolyte disorders). Additionally, renal artery stenosis is more common in patients over 65 years of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Antihypertensive combination therapy, e.g., with an ACE inhibitor, such as lisinopril, and a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, such as amlodipine, is the first-line treatment for all adults with systolic blood pressure ≥ 140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg. However, a diagnosis of true hypertension has not been established, so treatment is not indicated at this point.

D) CORRECT:

Out-of-office measurement is recommended in all individuals for confirmation of hypertension before initiating treatment. Ambulatory blood pressure measurement (ABPM) is the preferred method to distinguish between true hypertension and white coat hypertension in patients with elevated in-office blood pressure. ABPM records blood pressure at fixed intervals over 24 hours while the patient is carrying out regular activities. In-office readings between ≥ 130/89 mm Hg and ≤ 160/100 mm Hg in combination with out-of-office readings < 130/80 mm Hg confirm white coat hypertension (see “Interpretation of blood pressure readings“ table). Antihypertensive treatment is not necessary for patients with white coat hypertension. Instead, lifestyle modifications and cardiovascular risk reduction should be implemented. A repeat ABPM or home blood pressure monitoring (HBPM) should be done annually to monitor for progression to sustained hypertension. HBPM, an alternative option for recording out-of-office measurements, is done manually, requires patient training, and only records daytime blood pressure.

Out-of-office blood pressure measurement is also indicated in all patients with elevated in-office blood pressure readings to confirm hypertension prior to initiating antihypertensive treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although regular follow-up is necessary for patients with white coat hypertension, true hypertension must first be ruled out in these individuals. Reassurance alone in patients with white coat hypertension would not be sufficient, however, as lifestyle modifications and cardiovascular risk reduction are necessary interventions.
questions.hint: This otherwise healthy patient presents with repeatedly elevated blood pressure readings in a clinical setting and a normal blood pressure reading measured elsewhere. It is important to determine whether the elevated readings are caused by anxiety, (i.e., white coat hypertension) or by true hypertension.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with hypertension at his past three clinic visits has been reluctant to start additional medication without first trying lifestyle modifications. He recently purchased a home blood-pressure monitor and reports average readings at rest of 160/100 mm Hg while taking hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. He indicates that he is willing to change his medication as needed. His only other medical history is hyperlipidemia, for which he takes rosuvastatin.
His physical examination is unremarkable, and his blood pressure in the office today is 160/96 mm Hg. A previous evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension was unrevealing.
In addition to continued lifestyle modifications, which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Replace hydrochlorothiazide with furosemide 20 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, such as atenolol, are not very effective for the management of hypertension and are recommended primarily for patients with a history of myocardial infarction or existing angina. In addition, beta-blockers are no longer recommended as initial therapy because they appear to be less effective at preventing strokes.

B) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone and clonidine are not appropriate second-line drugs for the routine management of hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone and clonidine are not appropriate second-line drugs for the routine management of hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Switching from a thiazide diuretic to a loop diuretic at this dosage is unlikely to have any additional antihypertensive benefit. The mechanism of action of the loop diuretic may precipitate electrolyte abnormalities.

E) CORRECT:
