The 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association recommend a target blood pressure of < 130/80 mm Hg in patients with known cardiovascular disease, those with a 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease ≥ 10 %, and those with diabetes mellitus or chronic kidney disease. The same target blood pressure can reasonably be used in patients without these risk factors, such as the patient described in this vignette, but there is a lack of studies showing benefit from use of such a stringent target in this population. Therefore, it would also be reasonable to treat to a target blood pressure < 140/90 mm Hg in these lower-risk patients. In either case, this patient is above the target blood pressure and needs additional treatment.

The class of antihypertensive that should be considered in a patient who remains hypertensive despite treatment with hydrochlorothiazide is a long-acting calcium-channel blocker (such as amlodipine), angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin-receptor blocker.

Key learning point: The class of antihypertensive that should be considered in a patient who remains hypertensive despite treatment with hydrochlorothiazide is a long-acting calcium-channel blocker, angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin-receptor blocker.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents for management of hypertension. At his previous visit 8 weeks ago, his blood pressure was 180/95 mm Hg. He reports that he has stopped smoking and has restricted his salt intake since that visit. He is asymptomatic, with normal exercise tolerance.
Today, his initial blood pressure is 166/94 mm Hg in both arms, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute. A second blood pressure reading, obtained after he has been seated for 10 minutes, is similar. An S4 gallop is clearly audible on cardiac auscultation. He has no cardiac murmurs, no abdominal bruits, and no other abnormal findings. His serum electrolyte levels, urinalysis, and creatinine concentration are normal. An electrocardiogram shows no left ventricular hypertrophy.
In addition to initiating an antihypertensive medication, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

In a young, asymptomatic, hypertensive person with normal exercise tolerance, echocardiography is not indicated. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction would be very unlikely. Although the echocardiogram might demonstrate left ventricular hypertrophy or heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (diastolic dysfunction), those findings would not change the management of this case.

C) INCORRECT:

A serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide concentration, whether normal or abnormal, has limited diagnostic value in an asymptomatic patient and would not alter the management approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

E) CORRECT:

An S4 gallop is a common finding in patients with hypertension, resulting from forceful left atrial contraction and movement of blood into a hypertrophied left ventricle. Unlike an S3 gallop, an S4 gallop does not indicate ventricular systolic failure. An S4 gallop does not warrant further evaluation, but aggressive treatment of hypertension is indicated to prevent progression of end-organ effects.

Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. Indications to initiate evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension include symptoms, historical features, or physical examination findings that suggest a specific secondary cause of hypertension or one of the following criteria:

• Onset of hypertension before age 30
• Drug-resistant hypertension
• Abrupt onset of hypertension
• Exacerbation of previously controlled hypertension
• Disproportionate target-organ damage for the degree of hypertension
• Accelerated or malignant hypertension
• Onset of diastolic hypertension in adults age 65 years or older
• Unprovoked or excessive hypokalemia

This patient has none of these features and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

Key learning point: An S4 gallop is the most common physical finding on cardiac auscultation in patients with hypertension and does not warrant further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman with impaired glucose tolerance presents for routine follow-up. She feels well but acknowledges considerable family-related stress. She currently takes metformin 500 mg once daily.
Her systolic blood pressure has averaged about 136 mm Hg at her last several office visits, with an average diastolic pressure of 86 mm Hg. Her heart rate is 80 beats per minute, and her BMI is 32. Funduscopic examination reveals evidence of arteriovenous nicking. The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing reveals a glycated hemoglobin level of 6.2% (reference range, 4.3–5.6), a stable serum creatinine concentration of 1.0 mg/dL (0.6–1.1), a serum potassium level of 3.9 mEq/liter (3.5–5.0), and a normal complete blood count.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measuring a fructosamine level is unlikely to be diagnostically useful in a patient who has an elevated glycated hemoglobin level and whose complete blood count does not suggest a hemoglobinopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Searching for secondary causes of hypertension, such as renal artery stenosis, is premature in a patient without a confirmed diagnosis of hypertension or a reason to suspect secondary hypertension. Therefore, renal Doppler ultrasound is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s in-office blood pressure (BP) measurements are consistent with stage 1 hypertension (defined as BP 130–139 mm Hg or diastolic BP 80–89 mm Hg). Pharmacotherapy is not typically indicated for patients with stage 1 hypertension unless the patient has known cardiovascular disease, a 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease ≥10%, diabetes mellitus, or chronic kidney disease. Given that this patient does not have any of these conditions, pharmacotherapy may not, at first glance, seem to be indicated at this time.

However, the finding of arteriovenous nicking on funduscopic examination is unexpected in a patient with stage 1 hypertension and suggests chronic uncontrolled hypertension, which is more severe than initially suspected. Although this finding indicates that the patient will need treatment for hypertension, initiation of such treatment is not an emergency, and the clinician should therefore first evaluate for a cause of the discrepancy between the funduscopic findings and the office BP measurements.

The most likely explanation for this patient’s presentation is masked hypertension, a phenomenon in which a patient’s average BP outside the office is higher than in the office; the BP may even be normal during medical encounters despite sustained hypertension outside the clinic setting. Masked hypertension may occur in people with considerable stress in their daily lives. Smoking, alcohol use, and use of certain medications, such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, may exacerbate masked hypertension, just as they exacerbate conventionally diagnosed hypertension.

Assessment for masked hypertension is indicated in this patient before initiation of antihypertensive treatment. If masked hypertension were diagnosed, it would explain the discrepancy between the in-office BP readings and the funduscopic findings — and it would also mean that treating hypertension toward target in-office BP values would be misleading, because in masked hypertension, home BP values may remain elevated even while in-office BP values are controlled.

To assess for masked hypertension, the patient should undergo either home BP monitoring or ambulatory BP monitoring (ABPM). The 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association suggest confirming the diagnosis of hypertension with one of these methods in all patients with office systolic BP readings between 130 and 160 mm Hg or office diastolic BP readings between 80 and 100 mm Hg. This recommendation is consistent with those of the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, which recommend confirming hypertension with ABPM before initiating treatment. In addition to diagnosing masked hypertension, ABPM can help to establish a diagnosis of isolated clinic hypertension (white-coat hypertension) if BPs outside the clinic setting are normal.

Key learning point: A patient who has office blood pressure readings in the prehypertensive or mildly hypertensive range should be evaluated with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring.

D) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s lack of symptoms, there is no indication to perform an echocardiogram.

E) INCORRECT:

Initiating metoprolol in this patient would not be appropriate at this point. The patient’s home BPs need to be measured first to assess for masked hypertension which, if present, would make normalization of office BP measurements an inappropriate goal of therapy (normalization of home BP measurements should be the target). In addition, in current guidelines, beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are not considered first-line antihypertensive agents unless the patient has other indications for this drug class, such as coronary artery disease. Whether or not drug treatment is eventually instituted in this case, lifestyle modification (weight loss, exercise, and stress reduction) should be recommended strongly.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college athlete with no medical history or current medications is evaluated for hypertension. Her current blood pressure (BP) is 182/100 mm Hg; BP readings are similar in the upper and lower extremities. Previous office BP readings include 178/85 mm Hg last week and 185/90 mm Hg 6 months ago. BP measured with a cuff at home last week was 162/95 mm Hg in the right upper extremity. The patient’s dorsalis pedis pulses are bounding and symmetrically preserved, with no detectable radiofemoral delay.
Physical examination is unremarkable except for the elevated BP, with no detectable bruits. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, and inflammatory markers are all within normal limits.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma is a rare cause of secondary hypertension. About half of patients with pheochromocytoma have paroxysmal hypertension. Renal artery fibromuscular dysplasia is a more common cause of secondary hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism causing secondary hypertension is often associated with metabolic alkalosis, mild hypernatremia, and hypokalemia, and it is more common in older patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that can cause hypertension from renal artery involvement; however, patients usually have systemic symptoms, peripheral pulses may be diminished, and inflammatory markers are usually abnormal.

D) INCORRECT:

In aortic coarctation, blood pressure is typically lower in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities.

E) CORRECT:

About 5% of cases of hypertension in adults aged 18 to 39 have a secondary cause, most often thyroid disease, parenchymal kidney disease, or fibromuscular dysplasia. Hypertension in a patient in this age range increases the likelihood of secondary hypertension. If the patient is asymptomatic and has normal laboratory findings, the most likely diagnosis is renovascular hypertension related to fibromuscular dysplasia.

Key learning point: The most common cause of persistent renovascular hypertension in an asymptomatic young woman whose thyroid function, electrolyte levels, inflammatory markers, and kidney function are all normal is fibromuscular dysplasia.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes returns for follow-up after an office blood pressure reading, 12 weeks ago, of 139/88 mm Hg. He has since adhered to a new diet and exercise regimen, but on multiple measurements at home, his blood pressure has been consistently in the range of 135/85 mm Hg. His only medication is metformin.
At the current visit, two blood pressure readings, taken 5 minutes apart, are 138/88 and 136/86 mm Hg. His serum creatinine is at his baseline level of 1.5 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3), with a urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 240 mg/g (N < 30).
His electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm without left ventricular hypertrophy.
In addition to lifestyle modification, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although diuretics, calcium-channel blockers, beta-blockers, and alpha-blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

B) CORRECT:

Current guidelines from the American Diabetes Association, the American College of Cardiology, and the American Heart Association recommend initiation of antihypertensive drug therapy for patients with type 2 diabetes whose blood pressure persistently exceeds 130/80 mm Hg. This patient should therefore be started on an antihypertensive medication in addition to receiving lifestyle advice.

Given this patient’s type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and moderately increased albuminuria, the most appropriate first-line antihypertensive agent is either an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB). ACE inhibitors and ARBs are considered the most effective agents for slowing the rate of progression of proteinuria and kidney dysfunction. Of note, initiation of a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor should also be considered in this patient, as this class of drugs has been shown to slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line antihypertensive medication in a patient with type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and moderately increased albuminuria is either an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker.

C) INCORRECT:

Although diuretics, calcium-channel blockers, beta-blockers, and alpha-blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Although diuretics, calcium-channel blockers, beta-blockers, and alpha-blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Although diuretics, calcium-channel blockers, beta-blockers, and alpha-blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit with hypoxic respiratory failure. Her family states that she became acutely short of breath approximately 2 hours earlier. They also report that she has recently been evaluated for labile blood pressure, which at times reaches systolic pressures >200 mm Hg. She has intermittent headaches, sweating, and palpitations but no weight loss.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 37.5°C, a regular heart rate of 100 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 220/110 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% on 6 liters of supplemental oxygen. She is in moderate respiratory distress. No elevation in jugular venous pressure is detected, and heart sounds are unremarkable. Pulmonary auscultation reveals bilateral crackles to the mid-lung fields.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Serum creatinine levels and urinalysis are normal. An electrocardiogram shows deep T-wave inversions from V1 to V5. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals severe, diffuse, apical wall-motion abnormalities, with preserved function of the cardiac base.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to identify the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Serum aldosterone and plasma renin activity
Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone-producing tumors can cause hypertension but not heart failure.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with severe hypertension and acute heart failure has a clinical history consistent with pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytoma can lead to a catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy, which can manifest as severe, diffuse, apical wall-motion abnormalities, with preserved function of the base. The echocardiographic appearance is similar to that seen in stress-induced cardiomyopathy (also known as apical ballooning syndrome or Takotsubo cardiomyopathy). Electrocardiographic findings in a patient with pheochromocytoma-induced cardiomyopathy can include ST-segment elevation or diffuse T-wave inversion throughout the precordial leads. Markers of catecholamine excess (such as plasma metanephrines or urinary catecholamines and metanephrines) are typically diagnostic in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Key learning point: A patient with new-onset, episodic, severe hypertension associated with an acute cardiomyopathy characterized by apical dyskinesis but preserved function of the base should be evaluated for pheochromocytoma and an associated catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Renovascular disease can cause severe and labile hypertension, but it is not typically associated with acute heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with a hypercoagulable state that could result in coronary thrombosis, but it does not explain the preceding episodic severe hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Nuclear myocardial perfusion imaging can be helpful in evaluating patients for hibernating myocardium, but it would add little useful information in this patient with suspected catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man who has not seen a health care provider in many years presents for follow-up after a required preemployment electrocardiogram (figure). He has no notable medical history, feels well, and does not use tobacco or alcohol. He takes no medications.
His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a sustained apical impulse and no audible murmurs. His kidney function and serum electrolyte levels are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a rare cause of hypertension and resultant LVH and is often associated with impaired kidney function.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma that is sufficiently severe and chronic to cause LVH typically produces a range of symptoms, including headaches and palpitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with LVH but not hypertension. In addition, patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and significant left ventricular outflow-tract obstruction often have a murmur related to this obstruction or a mitral regurgitation murmur related to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

D) INCORRECT:

Although aortic stenosis can cause LVH, it does not cause hypertension and is easily identified by the presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

E) CORRECT:

This asymptomatic patient has primary hypertension, with electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). A sustained apical impulse indicates that LVH is present. The patient’s echocardiogram would be likely to show thickened LV walls and an elevated LV mass index.

Key learning point: The cardiac examination finding of a sustained apical impulse is most consistent with a diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. She has a past history of cigarette smoking and no family history of premature coronary heart disease. She has no symptoms of angina, carotid disease, or peripheral vascular disease. Her current medications are hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily, metformin 500 mg twice daily, and atorvastatin 20 mg daily.
She has a blood pressure of 145/94 mm Hg (similar to several recent readings at home) and a heart rate of 77 beats per minute. Heart and lung auscultation is normal. There is evidence of neuropathy on monofilament testing of the lower extremities.
Fasting lipid testing reveals a total cholesterol level of 200 mg/dL, an LDL-cholesterol level of 84 mg/dL, and an HDL-cholesterol level of 71 mg/dL. The patient’s baseline LDL-cholesterol 3 months ago, before starting atorvastatin, was 130 mg/dL.
What change(s), if any, should be made to this patient’s medication regimen?

choices.text: Increase the dose of lisinopril; switch atorvastatin to rosuvastatin
No change to lisinopril or atorvastatin
No change to lisinopril; increase the dose of atorvastatin
Increase the doses of both lisinopril and atorvastatin
Switch lisinopril to enalapril; no change to the dose of atorvastatin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Switching from atorvastatin to rosuvastatin is not indicated, as the patient is tolerating atorvastatin and has room to increase the dose to higher intensity.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated.

This patient will also require an increase in her statin dose.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated.

D) CORRECT:

According to current hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA), patients with type 2 diabetes who develop hypertension should start treatment at blood pressures (BPs) ≥130/80 and be treated to a target BP of <130/80 mm Hg. The American Diabetes Association recommends individualizing the BP target through a shared decision-making process, but using this same target of <130/80 mm Hg in most patients, assuming it can be safely attained. This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated. She will most likely need a third antihypertensive medication to reach her target BP and should therefore follow up within one month of starting a higher dose of lisinopril, to reassess her BP response.

This patient will also require an increase in her statin dose. According to the current ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guideline, all adults aged 40 to 75 who have type 2 diabetes should receive, at a minimum, a moderate-intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin 10–20 mg daily, rosuvastatin 5–10 mg daily, pravastatin 40–80 mg daily, lovastatin 40–80 mg, or simvastatin 20–40 mg daily), regardless of their estimated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. If a patient has multiple ASCVD risk factors (as in this case: age >60 years, hypertension, past smoking history, and diabetes-specific risk enhancers such as neuropathy), it is reasonable to attempt to lower the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% and to target an LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL by either intensifying therapy to a high-dose statin (e.g., atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily, rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) or adding other agents such as ezetimibe or a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) serine protease inhibitor. This patient’s LDL-cholesterol level has decreased by only 35% (from 130 mg/dL to 84 mg/dL) since she started a moderate-dose statin, and it remains above 70 mg/dL. The atorvastatin dose should therefore be increased.

Key learning point: In patients with type 2 diabetes, the target blood pressure is <130/80 mm Hg, and the goal for lipid-lowering therapy is to reduce the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% from baseline to a target level of <70 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Switching from lisinopril to enalapril is not indicated, as the patient is tolerating lisinopril and has room to increase the dose.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman with long-standing hypertension presents for follow-up. She is being treated with maximal doses of carvedilol, amlodipine, and benazepril. She has adhered to her medications and feels well.
Her blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 72 beats per minute. Her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
Her comprehensive metabolic panel and complete blood count are within normal limits, other than a serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) that is stable from one year ago.
Which one of the following additional treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol and labetalol are both dual alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptor blockers and should therefore not be taken in combination.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine, losartan, labetalol, and clonidine are all effective antihypertensive medications, but the best next choice is a diuretic.

C) INCORRECT:

An angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (benazepril) and an angiotensin-receptor blocker (losartan) should not be used in combination.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine, losartan, labetalol, and clonidine are all effective antihypertensive medications, but the best next choice is a diuretic.

E) CORRECT:

The 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association recommend a target blood pressure of <130/80 mm Hg in patients with known cardiovascular disease, those with a 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease ≥10%, and those with diabetes mellitus or chronic kidney disease. The same target blood pressure can reasonably be used even in patients without these risk factors, such as the patient described in this vignette, but there is a lack of studies showing benefit from the use of such a stringent target in this population. Therefore, it would also be reasonable to treat to a target blood pressure below 140/90 mm Hg in these lower-risk patients. In either case, this patient is above the target blood pressure and needs additional treatment.

This patient is not on a diuretic, but one should be added to her regimen. Treatment resistance in patients with hypertension is often due to underuse of diuretic therapy. The persistent blood pressure elevation is due in part to inappropriate, and often occult, intravascular volume expansion from blunted pressure natriuresis. Therefore, the addition or increase of diuretic therapy is an essential step in managing patients with difficult-to-control or resistant hypertension. In this scenario, the best medication to add would be a diuretic, such as chlorthalidone. Diuretic therapy is not contraindicated in patients with chronically impaired kidney function, although its effectiveness can be reduced in such patients, and monitoring of the renal function after initiation is prudent.

Key learning point: The most underused class of drugs in patients with difficult-to-control hypertension is diuretics.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents for evaluation of hypertension that was diagnosed 15 years ago. His blood pressure has been difficult to control despite his adherence to treatment with furosemide 40 mg, amlodipine 10 mg, lisinopril 40 mg, and atenolol 100 mg, all taken daily. He reports no other medical diagnoses and takes no other medications.
His current blood pressure is 162/89 mm Hg, and his BMI is 32.
Which one of the following findings would most likely be present on physical examination as a potential explanation for this patient’s drug-resistant hypertension?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (causing a radiofemoral pulse delay), Cushing syndrome (causing supraclavicular fat pads), and polycystic kidney disease (causing palpable kidneys) are seen in less than 1% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension

B) CORRECT:

A patient with drug-resistant hypertension (defined as uncontrolled blood pressure despite use of three or more antihypertensive medications, including one diuretic, at optimal doses) should be assessed for secondary causes of hypertension. The most common secondary causes of hypertension are primary hyperaldosteronism, renal-artery stenosis, chronic kidney disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Found in up to 83% of patients with difficult-to-control (resistant) hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea is one of the most common conditions associated with drug-resistant hypertension. A large neck circumference (>40 cm in women, >43 cm in men) suggests a greater likelihood of obstructive sleep apnea, as do male sex, general obesity, loud snoring, and daytime sleepiness. A crowded oral airway on examination would also support obstructive sleep apnea.

Key learning point: A patient with drug-resistant hypertension and a large neck size (>40 cm in women, >43 cm in men) should be screened for obstructive sleep apnea.

C) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (causing a radiofemoral pulse delay), Cushing syndrome (causing supraclavicular fat pads), and polycystic kidney disease (causing palpable kidneys) are seen in less than 1% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta (causing a radiofemoral pulse delay), Cushing syndrome (causing supraclavicular fat pads), and polycystic kidney disease (causing palpable kidneys) are seen in less than 1% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

An abdominal bruit can be detected occasionally in patients with renal-artery stenosis; however, renal-artery stenosis is present in only 3% to 4% of patients with drug-resistant hypertension.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is hospitalized after reporting chest pain, diaphoresis, palpitations, and left-sided abdominal and back pain. Her symptoms resolved before arrival at the emergency department. She reports that episodes of this nature have increased in frequency and severity during the past 18 months. Each episode lasts about 20 minutes and resolves spontaneously. Her outpatient clinicians attributed her symptoms to anxiety.
Her blood pressure is 159/82 mm Hg, her heart rate is 92 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37.4°C. She appears somewhat anxious. Physical examination is normal.
An electrocardiogram is normal other than occasional premature ventricular contractions. A CT of the abdomen is performed (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate to initiate next in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Preoperative management should focus on alpha- and beta-blockade. An alpha-blocker, such as phenoxybenzamine, should be started first. A beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) is often needed but should be initiated only after adequate alpha-blockade has been achieved. Use of a beta-blocker alone leads to unopposed action of catecholamines on the peripheral alpha-adrenergic receptors, which can worsen vasoconstriction and, thereby, the hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitotane is an adrenolytic medication used to treat adrenal cancer. Paroxysms of hypertension are not typical of adrenal cancers.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms typical of intermittent catecholamine release from a pheochromocytoma. The CT scan shows a large left-sided mass. In the setting of this constellation of symptoms, a pheochromocytoma should be considered the main differential diagnosis. The diagnosis needs to be confirmed with appropriate serum or urine blood tests and eventually managed with surgical resection, but at this point, medical management is the main priority. This includes control of hypertension and correction of volume contraction. The hypertension stems from the released catecholamines’ effects on alpha-adrenergic receptors (causing vasoconstriction) and beta-adrenergic receptors (causing increased heart rate and cardiac contractility).

Preoperative management should focus on alpha- and beta-blockade. An alpha-blocker, such as phenoxybenzamine, should be started first. A beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) is often needed but should be initiated only after adequate alpha-blockade has been achieved.

Key learning point: Hypertension in a patient with a pheochromocytoma should be managed with an alpha-blocker, such as phenoxybenzamine.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither hydralazine nor the mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist eplerenone would address the underlying pathophysiology of the hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Neither hydralazine nor the mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist eplerenone would address the underlying pathophysiology of the hypertension.

questions.text:
An asymptomatic 30-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension. About 5 years ago, he presented with blood pressures that were consistently about 170/110 mm Hg. For the past 3 years, he has been treated with lisinopril 20 mg daily and amlodipine 10 mg daily. His home blood pressures have recently been in the range of 150 to 160 mm Hg (systolic) and 90 to 100 mm Hg (diastolic).
He has a strong family history of hypertension. He does not use tobacco, alternative drugs, or recreational drugs. Past evaluations for renal artery stenosis and endocrine causes of hypertension were negative. An echocardiogram demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy.
On examination, his blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg, his heart rate is 74 beats per minute, and his BMI is 31. His cardiopulmonary and funduscopic examinations are normal. No abdominal bruits are noted, and the rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
139
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.2
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
102
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
28
21–30


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.8–1.3


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities.
In addition to counseling this patient on weight loss and exercise, which one of the following therapeutic approaches is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is usually recommended for hypertension that is resistant to at least three different classes of agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Adding an angiotensin-receptor antagonist, such as losartan, is not generally recommended for a patient already taking an ACE inhibitor because, in some studies, dual blockade of the renin-angiotensin system has been associated with increased risk for adverse effects without improving clinical outcomes.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has primary hypertension and needs additional treatment. The 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association recommend a target blood pressure of <130/80 mm Hg in patients with known cardiovascular disease, those with a 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease ≥10%, and those with diabetes mellitus or chronic kidney disease. The same target blood pressure can reasonably be used even in patients without these risk factors, such as the patient described in this vignette, but there is a lack of studies showing benefit from the use of such a stringent target in this population. Therefore, it would also be reasonable to treat to a target blood pressure <140/90 mm Hg in these lower-risk patients. In either case, this patient is above the target blood pressure and needs additional treatment.

Current guidelines recommend a thiazide-type diuretic, calcium-channel blocker (CCB), angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, or angiotensin-receptor blocker as initial treatment for hypertension. If the goal blood pressure (BP) cannot be achieved with one or two medications, additional drugs from this list should be initiated.

This patient’s BP control remains inadequate despite treatment with an ACE inhibitor and a CCB. Therefore, the best choice is to add a diuretic, such as chlorthalidone.

Key learning point: In patients with hypertension who require three drugs to achieve control, the drug classes that should usually be represented in the regimen are angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, calcium-channel blocker, and thiazide-type diuretic.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol) are a second-line therapy because they may confer inferior protection against stroke, especially in older individuals. In addition, a diuretic, rather than a beta-blocker, should be part of the regimen for a patient taking three or more antihypertensive agents because volume expansion generally plays a role in the pathophysiology of hypertension in such patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxazosin is generally not recommended for the treatment of blood pressure, because it increased the risk for heart failure in the Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Treatment to Prevent Heart Attack Trial (ALLHAT).

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman is noted to have a blood pressure of 153/93 mm Hg during a routine visit. The blood pressure is similar in both arms and confirmed on recheck. Her physical examination is otherwise normal. She is asymptomatic, and her BMI is 23.
Both of her parents and a 38-year-old brother have been diagnosed with hypertension. She drinks one cup of coffee every morning but states she does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She runs three times per week for approximately 30 minutes each time. She denies snoring or daytime sleepiness.
Her laboratory evaluation reveals normal levels of sodium, potassium, calcium, creatinine, and thyroid-stimulating hormone. A urinalysis and the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio are normal, as is an electrocardiogram.
She is taught how to measure her own blood pressure with a semi-automated home device and is asked to record her blood-pressure readings at home.
One month later, she returns for an office visit. Her blood pressure, taken with the office’s device, is 148/96 mm Hg after she is seated for 5 minutes; her home device yields a similar reading.
She presents a list of 15 home readings, taken at various times during the day, for review. They average 134/84 mm Hg, with most readings below 130/80 mm Hg, but several in the range of 150 to 160 systolic and 90 to 100 diastolic.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Repeat blood-pressure measurement on a caffeine-restricted diet
Measure plasma aldosterone and renin levels
Refer for an overnight sleep study

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

White-coat hypertension is a consideration in a patient who has mostly elevated blood pressures in the office, mostly normal readings at home, and no evidence of end-organ damage. If self-monitoring of blood pressure consistently reveals either elevated blood pressures or well-controlled blood pressure out of the office, 24-hour ambulatory measurements are not needed. Here, the patient’s reported home blood pressures demonstrate wide fluctuations: they are mostly normal but not consistently so. In such cases, ambulatory blood pressure monitoring can be used to confirm the diagnosis of white-coat hypertension.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for a patient being worked up for possible white-coat hypertension is ambulatory blood-pressure monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating the blood-pressure measurements on a caffeine-restricted diet is unnecessary. Although caffeine can raise the blood pressure slightly, it typically does not increase it by more than 10 mm Hg, and the effect is transient.

C) INCORRECT:

Some clinicians use an echocardiographic finding of left ventricular hypertrophy as a reason to begin drug therapy in a patient with labile or borderline hypertension, but this strategy has not been validated systematically in healthy young adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for hyperaldosteronism (aldosterone and renin measurements) is usually initiated in patients whose blood pressure is resistant to standard drug therapy, those with hypertension and unexplained hypokalemia, or those with significant hypokalemia from a low-dose thiazide.

E) INCORRECT:

Screening for obstructive sleep apnea is unnecessary in a healthy young woman without daytime sleepiness.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents for reassessment of multiple medical problems. He has no chest pain or dizziness. His medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes, and chronic kidney disease. His medications are chlorthalidone 12.5 mg daily, metoprolol 25 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg daily, aspirin 81 mg daily, and insulin.
His blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg (up from 136/72 mm Hg six months ago), his heart rate is 75 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute; he weighs 95 kg. Examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen is unremarkable. He has 1+ edema in both lower extremities.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5
13.5–17.5


Sodium (mEq/liter)
137
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
5.0
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
106
98–106


Carbon dioxide (mEq/liter)
21
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
42
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.5
0.8–1.3


Estimated glomerular filtration rate (mL/min/1.73 m2)
28
≥60


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
4.8
3.0–4.5


Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (mg/g)
375
<30


In addition to reviewing medication adherence with this patient, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing his hypertension?

choices.text: Increase the chlorthalidone dose to 25 mg daily
Increase the lisinopril dose to 40 mg daily
Switch chlorthalidone to torsemide 20 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone may help the edema and hypertension but is also likely to exacerbate the hyperkalemia.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has chronic kidney disease (CKD), and his blood pressure and albuminuria are suboptimally controlled. Improving blood pressure (BP) by any means is likely to improve albuminuria. This patient is taking three medications to control his BP, all at low to moderate doses. An increase in his chlorthalidone dose is likely to help improve his BP without raising his serum potassium level. It may also help address his mild edema. Chlorthalidone is a potent and long-acting thiazide-like diuretic. In the past, many clinicians believed that thiazide diuretics were unlikely to work in advanced CKD and recommended routinely shifting to loop diuretics when renal function declined. However, the Chlorthalidone in Chronic Kidney Disease (CLICK) trial disproved that theory and demonstrated that chlorthalidone is safe and effective in patients with CKD. In this placebo-controlled, 12-week trial involving patients with uncontrolled BP and stage 4 CKD, chlorthalidone was associated with an average systolic BP improvement of 10 mm Hg and a 50% reduction in the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio.

Key learning point: Optimizing the dose of thiazide diuretics is an effective strategy for hypertension management, even in patients with chronic kidney disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Increasing the lisinopril dose would help the albuminuria, but this patient’s serum potassium is already at the upper limit of normal.

D) INCORRECT:

If this patient’s BP does not improve with an increase in the chlorthalidone dose, replacing this medication with a long-acting loop diuretic like torsemide would be a good second-line choice, but it would be premature at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the addition of amlodipine may improve BP control, it will not address this patient’s volume expansion and edema. In fact, amlodipine may worsen lower-extremity edema.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with a 15-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, a 25-pack-year history of cigarette smoking before quitting 3 years ago, and a family history of myocardial infarction (father at age 50, mother at age 55) presents for routine follow-up. She has no complaints. Her current medications are lisinopril 20 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg daily, metformin 1000 mg daily, and empagliflozin 10 mg daily.
Her blood pressure is 144/84 mm Hg (similar to home blood-pressure readings during the past month), and her heart rate is 83 beats per minute. A recent lipid panel showed the following results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
146


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
42


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
68


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
180


The patient’s serum creatinine level has remained stable at 1.0 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) for more than 5 years. Her glycated hemoglobin level is 6.8% (4.3–5.6). Testing for increased albuminuria was negative on recent evaluation.
The patient’s 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is estimated at 4.3%.
Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate to further reduce this patient’s risk for cardiovascular disease?

choices.text: Continue current management with no changes
Switch the atorvastatin to rosuvastatin 20 mg
Recommend a low-fat diet to achieve a triglyceride level <150 mg/dL

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If this patient continued her current medication regimen without any changes, she would be missing an opportunity to reduce her cardiovascular risk by improving her BP control.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients at very high risk for ASCVD events (≥20%), it may be reasonable to add ezetimibe to maximally tolerated statin therapy to reduce LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% and to achieve an LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL. Given that this patient’s LDL-cholesterol level is already at target, there is no indication to add ezetimibe to her regimen.

C) INCORRECT:

Statin treatment is a cornerstone of cardiovascular risk reduction in patients both with and without type 2 diabetes. LDL-cholesterol treatment goals have largely been replaced by statin intensity recommendations in the current guidelines. In adults aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes and an LDL-cholesterol level of 70 to 189 mg/dL, a moderate-intensity statin is recommended. If a patient has multiple risk factors for ASCVD (as in this case), it is reasonable to prescribe high-intensity statin therapy with a goal of reducing the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% from baseline to a target level of <70 mg/dL. In this case, the patient is already taking a high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40 mg daily), and her LDL-cholesterol level is at goal; there is no indication to switch to another high-intensity statin, such as rosuvastatin 20 to 40 mg daily.

D) INCORRECT:

A healthy lifestyle should be recommended to this patient, but with mild hypertriglyceridemia, the preferred dietary approach is to focus on weight loss and avoid simple carbohydrates. This approach in combination with aerobic exercise can help reduce triglyceride levels, but its effect on the risk of cardiovascular disease is unlikely to be mediated solely through lowering of triglyceride levels. Given the results of the REDUCE-IT trial, one could consider adding icosapent ethyl to this patient’s regimen to lower her cardiovascular risk, although most patients in this trial had triglyceride levels >200 mg/dL.

E) CORRECT:

Given the increased risk for cardiovascular disease in patients with type 2 diabetes, managing cardiovascular risk factors in these patients should be a priority. In addition to long-standing type 2 diabetes, this patient has chronic hypertension, a family history of cardiovascular disease, and a history of tobacco use. Although she is not considered to be at high risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), it is still important to address her cardiovascular risk factors.

For treatment of hypertension in patients with diabetes, current guidelines from the American Diabetes Association (ADA) and the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) recommend a target blood pressure (BP) of <130/80 mm Hg. This patient’s BP is currently above this target; thus, her antihypertensive therapy should be intensified (for example, by increasing the dose of lisinopril).

Key learning point: Current guidelines recommend a target blood pressure of <130/80 mm Hg in patients with type 2 diabetes.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with a history of obesity and type 2 diabetes presents for his annual physical examination.
During the past several years, his ability to exercise has been steadily declining because of knee pain. He used to be able to walk for several miles without any symptoms, but now, he can walk for only a few minutes before the pain in his knees forces him to stop. He reports mild exertional dyspnea, which he believes is related to deconditioning. He reports no chest pain, palpitations, or other cardiac symptoms. His current medications are acetaminophen and ibuprofen (as needed for knee pain), lisinopril, atorvastatin, metformin, and semaglutide.
On physical examination, his heart rate is 68 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg, and his BMI is 34. Cardiac auscultation identifies an S4 gallop but is otherwise normal. Jugular venous pressure is 10 cm of water at 45 degrees, and trace lower-extremity edema is evident. The rest of the physical examination is normal.
Routine laboratory evaluation reveals a normal complete blood count, normal renal function, and normal coagulation parameters. The patient’s glycated hemoglobin concentration is 6.3% (reference range, 4.3–5.6), and his LDL-cholesterol level is 88 mg/dL (<130). An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next test for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s findings on electrocardiogram (ECG) are consistent with left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), likely related to chronic uncontrolled hypertension. Several methods can help to identify LVH on a patient’s ECG:

Sokolow-Lyon criteria

LVH is suspected if either of the following criteria are met:
• The sum of the S wave in lead V1 and the R wave in either lead V5 or lead V6 is ≥3.5 mV (35 mm)
• The R wave in lead aVL is ≥1.1 mV (11 mm)

Cornell criteria

LVH is suspected if the sum of the S wave in lead V3 and the R wave in lead aVL is >2.8 mV (28 mm) in men or >2.0 mV (20 mm) in women.

Romhilt-Estes point system

In this scoring system, 1 to 3 points are assigned for each of six ECG features. LVH is considered definite if a patient has a total score ≥5 points — and probable if the total score is 4 points.
• 3 points: In any limb lead, the R wave or S wave is ≥2.0 mV (20 mm), or the S wave in lead V1 or V2 is ≥3.0 mV (30 mm), or the R wave in lead V5 or V6 is ≥3.0 mV (30 mm)
• 3 points: ST/T-wave changes typical of LVH (“left ventricular strain” - ST-segment depression bowed upward and T-wave inversion; assign only 1 point if the patient is taking a digitalis compound)
• 3 points: Left atrial abnormality, as evident from P-terminal force (in lead V1) of ≥1 mm in depth and ≥40 msec (0.04 sec) in duration
• 2 points: Left-axis deviation –30° or more
• 1 point: QRS duration ≥90 msec (0.09 sec)
• 1 point: Intrinsicoid deflection (interval between the beginning of the QRS complex and the peak of the R wave) in lead V5 or V6 is ≥50 msec (0.05 sec)

This patient’s ECG meets precordial lead criteria for LVH according to Sokolow-Lyon criteria, as the approximate sum of the S wave in lead V1 (27 mm) and the R wave in lead V6 (32 mm) is 59 mm, which is above the 35-mm cutoff. In addition, the R wave in lead aVL is about 15 mm; thus, the second Sokolow-Lyon criterion is also fulfilled. The ECG also meets the Cornell criteria for LVH, as the approximate sum of the S wave in lead V3 (28 mm) plus the R wave in lead aVL (15 mm) is 43 mm, which is above the 28-mm cutoff for men. Finally, this ECG meets many of the criteria for LVH in the Romhilt-Estes point system, including the voltage criterion, the presence of ST/T-wave abnormalities, and ECG evidence of left atrial enlargement — for a score of at least 9, which indicates definite LVH. The clinical finding of S4 gallop is also consistent with LVH.

Imaging for LVH is not universally recommended during evaluation and management of hypertension in adults but should be considered in hypertensive patients who are young (<18 years), who have uncontrolled hypertension, who have secondary hypertension, whose blood pressure has been chronically uncontrolled, who have symptoms of heart failure, or who have ECG evidence of LVH. This patient should be further evaluated for LVH with imaging, both because of the ECG findings and because he has symptoms and signs that suggest heart failure (dyspnea on exertion, slightly elevated jugular venous pressure, and trace pedal edema). The imaging modality of choice is a complete transthoracic echocardiogram to evaluate for end-organ damage related to hypertension (not just for LVH but also for left atrial enlargement, diastolic dysfunction, systolic dysfunction, and other complications.).

Key learning point: The most appropriate next test to assess a patient who has suspected left ventricular hypertrophy, according to electrocardiographic criteria, is transthoracic echocardiography.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI would provide information about the degree and functional consequence of left ventricular hypertrophy, but a different imaging modality is typically the first-line test, given considerations of cost, accessibility, and institutional expertise in interpretation.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not appropriate as a first-line test in an intermediate-risk patient with possible ischemic heart disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has symptoms that could be attributable to angina, and further evaluation for coronary ischemia may be reasonable. However, the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy on the ECG reduces the accuracy of treadmill ECG testing. A stress test that encompasses an imaging modality (either stress echocardiography or myocardial perfusion imaging) would be a better option.

E) INCORRECT:

Holter monitoring is typically indicated to detect arrhythmias, especially if there are symptoms such as unexplained palpitations or syncope, which are not present in this case. In the context of left ventricular hypertrophy, Holter monitoring is not warranted unless there is a specific indication (e.g., identifying patients with confirmed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy who qualify for an implantable cardioverter defibrillator).

questions.text:
An asymptomatic 18-year-old male college student returns to clinic to review the results of his recent home blood pressure (BP) measurements. Two weeks ago, he presented for an evaluation before trying out for the rowing team at college. His BP at that initial office visit was 144/92 mm Hg in both arms; his physical examination was otherwise unremarkable. His mother and paternal uncle are being treated for hypertension.
His home BP measurements are 136/82, 130/88, and 134/80 mm Hg (average, 133/83 mm Hg). His current BP is 140/88 mm Hg in both his upper and lower extremities.
What is the most appropriate approach to manage this patient’s BP and sports activity clearance?

choices.text: Encourage lifestyle modification with no restriction in sports activity; repeat BP measurements in 3 months
Initiate treatment with lisinopril; restrict sports activity until BP is <130/80 mm Hg
Initiate treatment with hydrochlorothiazide; restrict sports activity until BP is <130/80 mm Hg
Encourage lifestyle modification; restrict sports activity until BP is <130/80 mm Hg
Refer for echocardiography; sports activity can be pursued if there is no left ventricular hypertrophy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure (BP) is consistently lower at home than in the office, a finding consistent with a diagnosis of white-coat hypertension; however, his home BP measurements are still elevated from normal. For patients ≥13 years of age, the hypertension guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) are now aligned with those from the American Heart Association (AHA), defining hypertension as outlined in the table below. Given the presence of white-coat hypertension in this patient, his home BP measurements should be used to classify his BP levels, and he should be diagnosed with stage 1 hypertension. Lifestyle modification without athletic restriction should be recommended, and BP should be reassessed in 3 months. Testing for secondary causes of hypertension is not considered necessary when there are no specific findings to suggest a secondary cause, when the patient has a family history of hypertension (as in this case), or the patient's BMI is in the overweight or obese range.

The AHA and AAP guidelines both recommend pharmacotherapy for stage 2 hypertension — or if stage 1 hypertension persists after implementation of lifestyle modifications, including the DASH diet. Although there is no direct evidence that initiating therapy to lower BP in this age group will lower the long-term risk of cardiovascular disease, there is some evidence that hypertension in adolescence contributes to premature atherosclerosis. Echocardiography should be performed at the time that pharmacotherapy is considered, to assess for left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). This patient does not qualify for pharmacotherapy at this time nor does he require echocardiography.

Restriction from competitive athletic participation is recommended for two groups of patients with hypertension until their hypertension is adequately treated:
• Those with BPs ≥140/90 who are involved in sports classified as high-static (e.g., weight lifting, boxing, and wrestling)
• Those found to have LVH or other evidence of end-organ damage on echocardiography
Given that return to play is extremely important to athletes, treatment and monitoring can be expedited to facilitate a safe return to sports. An acute elevation in systolic BP can occur with strenuous aerobic exercise, and an elevation in both systolic and diastolic BP can occur with resistance training. A slow, graduated training program with appropriate monitoring minimizes risk while allowing the benefit of exercise on BP.

Key learning point: In the setting of a preparticipation evaluation for a young adult athlete with a new diagnosis of stage 1 hypertension, lifestyle modification without athletic restriction should be recommended, and a follow-up BP measurement should be obtained in 3 months.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient does not qualify for pharmacotherapy at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient does not qualify for pharmacotherapy at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient should be diagnosed with stage 1 hypertension. Lifestyle modification without athletic restriction should be recommended, and BP should be reassessed in 3 months.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient does not require echocardiography at this time.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents for follow-up 2 weeks after treatment for a first episode of urinary tract infection. She is currently asymptomatic.
On the growth chart, her weight and height correlate to the 95th and 25th percentiles, respectively. Her temperature is 37.5°C, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure (BP) is 130/80 mm Hg. Her cardiac examination is within normal limits.
On two prior visits, her BP was 136/84 mm Hg and 130/81 mm Hg, and similar readings were obtained on home BP monitoring during the past month. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she is not taking any medications. When asked about family history, she mentions that her father was just diagnosed with hypertension and that her maternal grandmother had an acute myocardial infarction last year at age 72.
Urinalysis is normal.
What is the correct interpretation of this patient’s BP?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The classification for interpreting pediatric blood pressure (BP) changed in August 2017, with the release of new guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Standardized percentiles are still used for children <13 years of age, but the following cutoffs are now used for children ≥13 years of age: See “Classification of hypertension in children” table. The guideline also published new BP normative tables for children <13 years of age based on sex, age, and height. For all patients, measurements should be repeated at least three times for confirmation. BP is interpretable even in patients with minor illnesses, as long as they are not receiving medications that could affect the BP. This patient has had BPs in the range of stage 1 hypertension on three separate occasions and so meets the diagnostic criteria. Ambulatory BP monitoring is recommended for further evaluation and diagnostic certainty.

The American Academy of Pediatrics Bright Futures program, the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, and the American Heart Association recommend BP screening annually at well-child visits beginning at age 3. However, more research is needed to determine the value of pediatric primary hypertension screening in preventing future cardiovascular disease. Risk factors for primary hypertension in the pediatric population include elevated BMI, male sex, low birth weight, Black race, and a family history of hypertension. Although frequent urinary tract infections (UTIs) might predispose to hypertension due to renal disease, a first UTI at age 16 that has been treated should not affect a patient’s BP readings.

Key learning point: In children ≥13 years of age, stage 1 hypertension is diagnosed on the basis of repeated BP measurements between 130/80 and 139/89 mm Hg.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has had BPs in the range of stage 1 hypertension on three separate occasions. See “Classification of hypertension in children” table.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has had BPs in the range of stage 1 hypertension on three separate occasions. See “Classification of hypertension in children” table.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has had BPs in the range of stage 1 hypertension on three separate occasions. See “Classification of hypertension in children” table.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has had BPs in the range of stage 1 hypertension on three separate occasions and so meets the diagnostic criteria. See “Classification of hypertension in children” table.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy with no significant medical history or current health concerns presents for routine medical care. His weight is in the 90th percentile for his age and sex, his height is in the 25th percentile, and his BMI is at >95th percentile.
His current temperature is 37.8°C, his heart rate is 95 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. His blood pressure (BP) in his right arm is 109/80 mm Hg (systolic BP at the 90th percentile and diastolic BP at >95th percentile for age, sex, and height).
Before diagnosing this patient with hypertension, which one of the following steps should be taken?

choices.text: Repeat the BP measurement in the right arm using a cuff whose bladder length is 80% to 100% of the patient’s arm circumference
Repeat the BP measurement in the right arm, but use Korotkoff sounds 1 and 4 to identify the systolic and diastolic pressures
Repeat the BP measurement in the right arm 2 to 3 minutes after the child takes a relaxing walk with a parent
Reassure the family that the patient is experiencing white-coat hypertension
Measure the child's BP in the left arm using a stethoscope and manual sphygmomanometer

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics describe a standardized technique for obtaining blood pressure (BP) readings in children:

• BP measurements should be taken in the right arm for consistency and for comparison with values in standardized tables. Measurements in the left arm may be artificially low in the presence of coarctation of the aorta. The arm should be uncovered and supported at the level of the heart.
• Children should be seated for 3 to 5 minutes before BP measurement, with their back supported and their feet on the floor. BP should not be measured after activity, including walks.
• The bladder length of the cuff should be 80% to 100% of the circumference of the patient’s arm, and the width should be at least 40%.
• In children, Korotkoff sound 1 is correlated to systolic BP, and Korotkoff sound 5 is correlated to diastolic BP. Using Korotkoff sound 4 for BP measurement is therefore not appropriate.

Notably, some children experience anxiety in a doctor’s office, resulting in white-coat hypertension. If a child's BP is borderline elevated in the office, repeat values can be obtained by the school nurse, or ambulatory BP monitoring can be ordered. Dismissing elevated BPs without follow-up is not appropriate.

Key learning point: When obtaining accurate BP measurements in the pediatric population, the appropriate cuff size should be based on the child’s arm circumference.

B) INCORRECT:

In children, Korotkoff sound 1 is correlated to systolic BP, and Korotkoff sound 5 is correlated to diastolic BP. Using Korotkoff sound 4 for BP measurement is therefore not appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Children should be seated for 3 to 5 minutes before BP measurement, with their back supported and their feet on the floor. BP should not be measured after activity, including walks.

D) INCORRECT:

If a child's BP is borderline elevated in the office, repeat values can be obtained by the school nurse, or ambulatory BP monitoring can be ordered. Dismissing elevated BPs without follow-up is not appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

BP measurements should be taken in the right arm for consistency and for comparison with values in standardized tables. Measurements in the left arm may be artificially low in the presence of coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents for routine evaluation. His blood pressure (BP), when measured with an oscillometric device, is found to be 134/82 mm Hg, a level consistent with stage 1 hypertension. The measurement is repeated later during the visit and found to be unchanged.
He returns to the office on two other occasions, and his BP, when measured by manual auscultation and with an appropriately sized BP cuff, remains in the same range.
His height is at the 60th percentile, his weight is at the 95th percentile, and his BMI is 31.8 (98th percentile). His physical examination is unremarkable; there is no radiofemoral delay and no bruits.
A screening urinalysis is normal.
In addition to follow-up in-office BP measurements and therapeutic lifestyle modifications, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries
24-hour urine collection to measure catecholamines and metanephrines

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal Doppler ultrasound is used to screen for renal artery stenosis, a common cause of secondary hypertension. However, testing should not be pursued until hypertension has been confirmed with ambulatory BP monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram can be used to identify structural cardiac abnormalities and coarctation of the aorta. Echocardiography can also reveal left ventricular hypertrophy, the most common form of hypertensive target-organ damage in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of fasting insulin levels is not part of the evaluation for hypertension but may be used to evaluate insulin resistance or in the evaluation of patients with hypoglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Catecholamines and metanephrines are elevated in patients with pheochromocytoma but should not be measured initially unless the patient presents with other features to suggest the diagnosis (e.g., tachycardia, episodic flushing, or postural hypotension).

E) CORRECT:

The classification for interpreting pediatric blood pressure (BP) changed in August 2017, with the release of new guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Standardized percentiles are still used for children <13 years of age, but the following cutoffs are now used for children ≥13 years of age: See “Classification of hypertension in children” table.

Any child or adolescent with hypertension should be examined carefully to identify symptoms or signs of renal, cardiac, or systemic disorders that are associated with hypertension. Screening BPs should be taken in the right arm, while the child is sitting with feet on the floor, after 3 to 5 minutes of quiet rest. If the BP is persistently elevated, it should also be measured in the left arm and one leg to evaluate for coarctation of the aorta.

Before a workup for secondary causes of hypertension is initiated, ambulatory BP monitoring (in which the patient has frequent measurements taken by a portable device as he goes about everyday life) should be undertaken to determine whether the patient has white-coat hypertension, which does not require additional evaluation, or whether he has sustained hypertension. If stage 1 hypertension is confirmed, the patient would require further investigation. When obesity is a contributing factor, it should be addressed with therapeutic lifestyle modifications (increased aerobic activity and dietary modifications).

Key learning point: When stage 1 hypertension is suspected in an asymptomatic adolescent based on three in-office BP measurements, the best step for confirming the diagnosis is ambulatory BP monitoring.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents for follow-up several days after her blood pressure (BP) was measured at 136/86 mm Hg during a routine evaluation. A follow-up BP measurement by her school nurse was recorded at 134/82 mm Hg. Since she was last seen, the patient has had intermittent headaches and today reports a headache that she rates as 6 out of 10 in intensity.
Her current BP, measured with an appropriately sized manual cuff, is 142/90 mm Hg in both arms. She has a normal physical examination. A point-of-care urinalysis is normal.
What is the most appropriate immediate next step in managing this patient's elevated BP?

choices.text: Measure plasma catecholamines, metanephrines, and plasma renin activity
Arrange follow-up within the next week to repeat the BP measurement
Order a 24-hour urine collection for calcium, phosphate, and creatinine
Measure the level of thyroid-stimulating hormone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plasma catecholamine and metanephrine measurements can be used to identify pheochromocytoma, but this diagnosis is uncommon. Consequently, these measurements are not initially obtained unless the patient exhibits tachycardia and postural hypotension. Plasma renin activity, which is low in children with mineralocorticoid excess, is an appropriate test for children with hypokalemia or adrenal hyperplasia.

B) CORRECT:

In children <13 years of age, hypertension is defined as three separate measurements of blood pressure (BP) that are at or above the 95th percentile for the patient’s age, height, and sex. Stage 2 hypertension in this age group is defined as BP ≥95th percentile + 12 mm Hg, or ≥140/90 mm Hg (whichever is lower). New normative tables for percentiles were published in the 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics.

Children with stage 2 hypertension who are symptomatic, as in this case (headaches), should be referred for immediate care, such as to an emergency department. Treatment or referral to a specialist is indicated when repeat BP measurements are in the stage 2 range for more than one week.

Initial evaluation should focus on identifiable causes of hypertension. The most common cause of secondary hypertension in children is kidney disease. Urinalysis and measurement of serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and electrolytes can be obtained quickly and may identify potential causes, such as chronic kidney disease or glomerulonephritis. Renal ultrasound can identify anatomic abnormalities, such as size asymmetry and hydronephrosis, and is also part of the first-line evaluation.

Key learning point: Children with stage 2 hypertension should be referred to the emergency department if they are symptomatic or their BP is >30 mm Hg above the 95th percentile (or >180/120 mm Hg in an adolescent).

C) INCORRECT:

Simply arranging follow-up to repeat the BP measurement would be inappropriate in a symptomatic child who has more than one BP reading in the hypertensive range.

D) INCORRECT:

24-hour urine collection for calcium, phosphate, and creatinine is not part of the initial evaluation of a child with hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid testing is not part of the initial evaluation of a child with hypertension.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents for follow-up of a blood pressure (BP) reading of 125/81 mm Hg at a well-child visit 2 weeks ago. He has no complaints, but in triage, his initial BP reading in his right upper extremity using an appropriately sized cuff is 130/85 mm Hg. A repeat BP measurement 20 minutes later is 131/86 mm Hg.
His physical examination is otherwise notable only for a BMI at the 90th percentile.
In addition to ambulatory BP monitoring, which one of the following evaluations is the best next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the latest hypertension guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics (2017), the classification of blood pressure (BP) values for children ≥13 years of age has been simplified to match adult ranges. See “Classification of hypertension in children” table. BP readings should be confirmed on separate occasions before making a formal diagnosis of hypertension. This patient has had BPs in the range of stage 1 hypertension on two separate occasions. At this second visit, lower-extremity measurements should be obtained to assess for coarctation of the aorta as a cause of the hypertension, and ambulatory BP monitoring should be arranged. In patients with a coarctation of the aorta, BP is typically lower in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities.

The prevalence of hypertension in children, when defined by repeat measurements, is approximately 3.5%. Children with obesity have higher rates of hypertension, and the prevalence of hypertension appears to increase with increasing BMI. Primary hypertension is currently the most frequent cause of hypertension in referral centers. The degree of hypertension often helps determine the need for further evaluation. Those with mild BP elevations may warrant dietary counseling and lifestyle modification, whereas any child or adolescent with severe BP elevation should be referred to subspecialty care. A careful history and physical examination are important for assessing which patients might require further evaluation. Physical signs that raise suspicion for a secondary cause include tachycardia (pheochromocytoma, hyperthyroidism), moon facies (glucocorticoid use, Cushing syndrome), papilledema (increased intracranial pressure), adenotonsillar hypertrophy (obstructive sleep apnea), malar rash (systemic lupus erythematosus), higher BP in the upper than lower extremities (coarctation of the aorta), and abdominal or flank bruit (renal artery stenosis).

Key learning point: When a child has hypertension, BP measurements in the lower extremity should be obtained to rule out coarctation of the aorta.

B) INCORRECT:

A sleep study should be considered if there is concern for obstructive sleep apnea as a cause of hypertension, but the most urgent next step for this patient is to rule out coarctation of the aorta and confirm hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine and plasma steroid levels can be diagnostic when evaluating a patient for Cushing syndrome, but this patient has no other associated symptoms to warrant this workup.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasma metanephrine levels should be obtained when considering a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, but this patient has no other symptoms to suggest this diagnosis (e.g., tachycardia or diaphoresis).

E) INCORRECT:

A head CT is not indicated in this case, as the patient has no symptoms or signs to suggest increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text:
A healthy 16-year-old boy with recently diagnosed stage 2 hypertension presents for clearance to participate in high school sports. He has a negative review of symptoms, takes no medications, and has an unremarkable family history. He reports no sexual activity, smoking, or drug use. He currently works with a nutrition and lifestyle coach and is hoping to engage in school sports as part of his lifestyle modification.
In addition to undergoing ambulatory blood-pressure (BP) monitoring, he has had normal blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, lipid profile, and urinalysis findings in the past month. He has also had a normal echocardiogram.
Today, he has a heart rate of 60 beats per minute, a left-arm BP of 140/86 mm Hg, and a right-arm BP of 145/90 mm Hg. His physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient regarding sports participation?

choices.text: Restrict the patient from high-dynamic sports (e.g., soccer, cross-country running, and squash)
Restrict the patient from high-static sports (e.g., weightlifting, boxing, and wrestling)
Clear the patient for all sports participation
Obtain a urine drug test for cocaine and amphetamines

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology, athletes who have stage 2 hypertension (with or without end-organ dysfunction) should be restricted from high-static sports (e.g., weightlifting, boxing, and wrestling) until their BP is well controlled. Systolic and diastolic BPs are relatively lower with aerobic (high-dynamic) exercise.

B) CORRECT:

The preparticipation examination is an important opportunity to prevent and detect conditions that predispose patients to harm during sports activities. One important aspect of that evaluation is measuring blood pressure (BP), which is classified as follows in patients ≥13 years old: See “Classification of hypertension in children” table.
