BP readings should be confirmed on separate occasions before a formal diagnosis of hypertension is made. In this case, the patient has confirmed stage 2 hypertension.

According to the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology, athletes who have stage 2 hypertension (with or without end-organ dysfunction) should be restricted from high-static sports (e.g., weightlifting, boxing, and wrestling) until their BP is well controlled. During resistance exercise (static sports), both systolic and diastolic BP increase, which may increase the risks for myocardial infarction and sudden death. Systolic and diastolic BPs are relatively lower with aerobic (high-dynamic) exercise.

Initial management for hypertension is focused on lifestyle modification, although patients with stage 2 hypertension are candidates for pharmacotherapy. The most commonly used antihypertensives in athletes are angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers, and calcium-channel blockers. Beta-blockers and diuretics are typically avoided in this population because many of these agents are banned in certain sports at the collegiate and professional level.

Key learning point: Adolescent athletes who have stage 2 hypertension (with or without end-organ dysfunction) should be restricted from high-static sports (e.g., weightlifting, boxing, and wrestling) until their blood pressure is well controlled.

C) INCORRECT:

Initial management for hypertension is focused on lifestyle modification, although patients with stage 2 hypertension are candidates for pharmacotherapy. The most commonly used antihypertensives in athletes are angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers, and calcium-channel blockers. Beta-blockers and diuretics are typically avoided in this population because many of these agents are banned in certain sports at the collegiate and professional level.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology, athletes who have stage 2 hypertension (with or without end-organ dysfunction) should be restricted from high-static sports (e.g., weightlifting, boxing, and wrestling) until their BP is well controlled.

E) INCORRECT:

Although certain drugs such as cocaine and amphetamines do increase blood pressure, routine urine testing is not indicated in patients with hypertension who do not report use of these drugs.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college athlete with no medical history or current medications is evaluated for hypertension. Her current blood pressure (BP) is 182/100 mm Hg; BP readings are similar in the upper and lower extremities. Previous office BP readings include 178/85 mm Hg last week and 185/90 mm Hg 6 months ago. BP measured with a cuff at home last week was 162/95 mm Hg in the right upper extremity. The patient’s dorsalis pedis pulses are bounding and symmetrically preserved, with no detectable radiofemoral delay. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, and inflammatory markers are all within normal limits. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma is a rare cause of secondary hypertension. About half of patients with pheochromocytoma have paroxysmal hypertension. A different condition is a more common cause of secondary hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism causing secondary hypertension is often associated with metabolic alkalosis, mild hypernatremia, and hypokalemia, and it is more common in older patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that can cause hypertension from renal artery involvement; however, patients usually have systemic symptoms, peripheral pulses may be diminished, and inflammatory markers are usually abnormal.

D) INCORRECT:

In aortic coarctation, blood pressure is typically lower in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities.

E) CORRECT:

About 5% of cases of hypertension in adults aged 18 to 39 have a secondary cause, most often thyroid disease, parenchymal kidney disease, or fibromuscular dysplasia. Hypertension in a patient in this age range increases the likelihood of secondary hypertension. If the patient is asymptomatic and has normal laboratory findings, the most likely diagnosis is renovascular hypertension related to fibromuscular dysplasia.

Key learning point: The most common cause of persistent renovascular hypertension in an asymptomatic young woman whose thyroid function, electrolyte levels, inflammatory markers, and kidney function are all normal is fibromuscular dysplasia.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who has not seen a health care provider in many years presents for follow-up after a required preemployment electrocardiogram (figure). He has no notable medical history, feels well, and does not use tobacco or alcohol. He takes no medications. His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a sustained apical impulse and no audible murmurs. His kidney function and serum electrolyte levels are normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a rare cause of hypertension and resultant LVH and is often associated with impaired kidney function.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma that is sufficiently severe and chronic to cause LVH typically produces a range of symptoms, including headaches and palpitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with LVH but not hypertension. In addition, patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and significant left ventricular outflow-tract obstruction often have a murmur related to this obstruction or a mitral regurgitation murmur related to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

D) INCORRECT:

Although aortic stenosis can cause LVH, it does not cause hypertension and is easily identified by the presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

E) CORRECT:

This asymptomatic patient has primary hypertension, with electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). A sustained apical impulse indicates that LVH is present. The patient’s echocardiogram would be likely to show thickened LV walls and an elevated LV mass index.

Key learning point: The cardiac examination finding of a sustained apical impulse is most consistent with a diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for management of hypertension. At his previous visit 8 weeks ago, his blood pressure was 180/95 mm Hg. He reports that he has stopped smoking and has restricted his salt intake since that visit. He is asymptomatic, with normal exercise tolerance. Today, his initial blood pressure is 166/94 mm Hg in both arms, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute. An S4 gallop is clearly audible on cardiac auscultation. He has no cardiac murmurs, no abdominal bruits, and no other abnormal findings. His serum electrolyte levels, urinalysis, and creatinine concentration are normal. An electrocardiogram shows no left ventricular hypertrophy. In addition to initiating an antihypertensive medication, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

In a young, asymptomatic, hypertensive person with normal exercise tolerance, echocardiography is not indicated. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction would be very unlikely. Although the echocardiogram might demonstrate left ventricular hypertrophy or heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (diastolic dysfunction), those findings would not change the management of this case.

C) INCORRECT:

A serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide concentration, whether normal or abnormal, has limited diagnostic value in an asymptomatic patient and would not alter the management approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

E) CORRECT:

An S4 gallop is a common finding in patients with hypertension, resulting from forceful left atrial contraction and movement of blood into a hypertrophied left ventricle. Unlike an S3 gallop, an S4 gallop does not indicate ventricular systolic failure. An S4 gallop does not warrant further evaluation, but aggressive treatment of hypertension is indicated to prevent progression of end-organ effects.

Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. Indications to initiate evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension include symptoms, historical features, or physical examination findings that suggest a specific secondary cause of hypertension or one of the following criteria:

• Onset of hypertension before age 30
• Drug-resistant hypertension
• Abrupt onset of hypertension
• Exacerbation of previously controlled hypertension
• Disproportionate target-organ damage for the degree of hypertension
• Accelerated or malignant hypertension
• Onset of diastolic hypertension in adults age 65 years or older
• Unprovoked or excessive hypokalemia

This patient has none of these features and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

Key learning point: An S4 gallop is the most common physical finding on cardiac auscultation in patients with hypertension and does not warrant further evaluation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes returns for follow-up after an office blood pressure reading, 12 weeks ago, of 139/88 mm Hg. He has since adhered to a new diet and exercise regimen, but on multiple measurements at home, his blood pressure has been consistently in the range of 135/85 mm Hg. His only medication is metformin. At the current visit, two blood pressure readings, taken 5 minutes apart, are 138/88 and 136/86 mm Hg. His serum creatinine is at his baseline level of 1.5 mg/dL, with a urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 240 mg/g (< 30). Electrocardiography shows normal sinus rhythm without left ventricular hypertrophy. In addition to lifestyle modification, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although beta-blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

B) CORRECT:

Current guidelines from the American Diabetes Association, the American College of Cardiology, and the American Heart Association recommend initiation of antihypertensive drug therapy for patients with type 2 diabetes whose blood pressure persistently exceeds 130/80 mm Hg. This patient should therefore be started on an antihypertensive medication in addition to receiving lifestyle advice.

Given this patient’s type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and moderately increased albuminuria, the most appropriate first-line antihypertensive agent is either an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB). ACE inhibitors and ARBs are considered the most effective agents for slowing the rate of progression of proteinuria and kidney dysfunction. Of note, initiation of a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor should also be considered in this patient, as this class of drugs has been shown to slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line antihypertensive medication in a patient with type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and moderately increased albuminuria is either an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker.

C) INCORRECT:

Although diuretics can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Although calcium-channel blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Although alpha-blockers can be used in patients with type 2 diabetes, an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is more appropriate for a patient with chronic kidney disease and moderately increased albuminuria.

questions.text:
An asymptomatic 30-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension. For the past 3 years, he has been treated with daily lisinopril and amlodipine. His home blood pressures have recently been in the range of 150 to 160 mm Hg (systolic) and 90 to 100 mm Hg (diastolic). Past evaluations for renal artery stenosis and endocrine causes of hypertension were negative. An echocardiogram demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy. On examination, his blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg, pulse is 74/min, and his BMI is 31 kg/m2. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Sodium
139 mEq/L


Potassium
4.2 mEq/L


Chloride
102 mEq/L


Bicarbonate
28 mEq/L


Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


In addition to counseling this patient on weight loss and exercise, which one of the following therapeutic approaches is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is usually recommended for hypertension that is resistant to at least three different classes of agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Adding an angiotensin-receptor antagonist, such as losartan, is not generally recommended for a patient already taking an ACE inhibitor because, in some studies, dual blockade of the renin-angiotensin system has been associated with increased risk for adverse effects without improving clinical outcomes.

C) CORRECT:

The 2017 hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association recommend a target blood pressure of <130/80 mm Hg in patients with known cardiovascular disease, those with a 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease ≥10%, and those with diabetes mellitus or chronic kidney disease. The same target blood pressure can reasonably be used even in patients without these risk factors, such as the patient described in this vignette, but there is a lack of studies showing benefit from the use of such a stringent target in this population. Therefore, it would also be reasonable to treat to a target blood pressure <140/90 mm Hg in these lower-risk patients. In either case, this patient is above the target blood pressure and needs additional treatment.

Current guidelines recommend a thiazide-type diuretic, calcium-channel blocker (CCB), angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin-receptor blocker as initial treatment for hypertension, with the first two classes being preferred for initial therapy in the general Black population. If the goal blood pressure (BP) cannot be achieved with one or two medications, additional drugs from this list should be initiated.

This patient’s BP control remains inadequate despite treatment with an ACE inhibitor and a CCB. Therefore, the best choice is to add a diuretic, such as chlorthalidone.

Key learning point: In patients with hypertension who require three drugs to achieve control, the drug classes that should usually be represented in the regimen are angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, calcium-channel blocker, and thiazide-type diuretic.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers (e.g., atenolol) are a second-line therapy because they may confer inferior protection against stroke, especially in older individuals. In addition, a diuretic, rather than a beta-blocker, should be part of the regimen for a patient taking three or more antihypertensive agents because volume expansion generally plays a role in the pathophysiology of hypertension in such patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxazosin is generally not recommended for the treatment of blood pressure, because it increased the risk for heart failure in the Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Treatment to Prevent Heart Attack Trial (ALLHAT).
questions.hint: This patient has primary hypertension and needs additional treatment.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up appointment because of a blood pressure of 148/98 mm Hg at her last health maintenance examination four weeks ago. She feels well. She has a history of migraine with aura of moderate to severe intensity. For the past year, the frequency of headaches has been increasing and they now occur 1–2 times per week. Her blood pressure is 143/92 mm Hg. A repeat sitting blood pressure 20 minutes later is 145/94 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) can be used as first-line treatment of hypertension, especially in patients with isolated systolic hypertension. However, this patient would benefit more from a medication that can also target her worsening migraine headaches.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) are considered first-line treatment for hypertension. However, this patient with a history of worsening migraine headaches would benefit more from an alternative antihypertensive that can treat both of her medical problems. Moreover, ACE inhibitors should generally be avoided in female patients of reproductive age that are sexually active and use contraception inconsistently, as they are known to be teratogenic.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with both hypertension and a history of migraine requiring prophylactic therapy, beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are an adequate first-line alternative as they target both conditions. In patients with hypertension and no other comorbidities, thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitor, calcium channel blockers, and/or angiotensin-receptor blockers should be tried first, before administering a beta blocker.

See “Antihypertensive treatment by comorbidities” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-receptor blockers (e.g., losartan) can be used as first-line treatment for hypertension. However, this patient with a history of worsening migraine headaches would benefit more from an alternative antihypertensive that can treat both of her medical problems. Moreover, ARB should be avoided in female patients of reproductive age that are sexually active, as they are known to be teratogenic.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertension and a history of increasingly frequent migraine headaches, making a specific medication more appropriate in this case.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and asthma comes to the office because of a 2-month history of intermittent dry, hacking cough. He does not have fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He does not smoke cigarettes. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, albuterol, and ramipril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action?

choices.text: Start dextromethorphan and increase frequency of albuterol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dextromethorphan is an NMDA glutamate receptor antagonist used as an over-the-counter cough suppressant and albuterol is a beta-2 agonist used in the treatment of asthma. While dextromethorphan might temporarily mitigate this patient's cough, it would not address the root cause of it. Additionally, there is no other evidence that this patient's cough is associated with an asthma exacerbation (such as dyspnea, wheezing, or chest tightness); increasing albuterol is therefore unlikely to resolve this problem.

B) INCORRECT:

Both simvastatin and atorvastatin are statins, which are indicated to treat hyperlipidemia and act by decreasing LDL levels. Classic side effects of statins include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis but not cough. Therefore, changing the patient's medication from simvastatin to atorvastatin would be unlikely to resolve his cough.

C) CORRECT:

Dry cough is a characteristic side effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Inhibition of ACE also causes an increase in bradykinin, which can lead to bronchoconstriction and dry cough. If cough caused by ACE inhibitors is present, discontinuation of ACE inhibitors and switching to angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) such as candesartan is recommended. Cough is a rare adverse effect of ARBs, as these agents do not influence the breakdown of kinins.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include hypotension, hyperkalemia, a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and angioedema.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

D) INCORRECT:

Ramipril and lisinopril are both angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). A common side effect of treatment with ACE inhibitors is an intermittent, nonproductive cough, such as the one seen in this patient. Because all ACE inhibitors are known to cause this cough, switching from one agent to another within this class would be unlikely to resolve the problem.

E) INCORRECT:

Albuterol and salmeterol are both beta-2 adrenergic agonists used in the treatment of asthma. While albuterol is a short-acting agent used for acute asthma exacerbations, salmeterol is a long-acting agent used for prophylaxis of asthma attacks. Although this patient has a history of asthma, his current cough seems unrelated to it. He does not have a history or findings to suggest exacerbation of asthma (e.g., exposure to triggers, dyspnea, or tachypnea on examination). Moreover, stopping albuterol would not be appropriate if there was any suspicion of an asthma exacerbation.
questions.hint: Increased local concentrations of bradykinin and substance P are thought to be responsible for the symptom this patient is experiencing.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of fatigue and swelling of the lower legs for 3 weeks. One year ago, he had an 85% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery, for which he received 2 stents. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C 5 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and arterial hypertension. Current medications include aspirin, metformin, and ramipril. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Serum



 Na+
137 mEq/L


 K+
5.2 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL


 Creatinine

3.9 mg/dL


 Albumin
3.6 g/dL


Urinalysis discloses 1+ glucose and 3+ protein. A renal biopsy shows sclerosis in the capillary tufts and arterial hyalinosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is a potential cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. While this condition can be associated with chronic infections (such as hepatitis C) and would result in proteinuria and peripheral edema, amyloidosis classically presents in patients with multiple myeloma and signs of extrarenal organ involvement, such as restrictive cardiomyopathy, as opposed to coronary artery disease. Moreover, renal biopsy in amyloidosis would show green birefringence under Congo red stain.

B) CORRECT:

Hypertensive nephrosclerosis results from renal vascular injury secondary to long-standing arterial hypertension. Sclerosis in the capillary tufts and hyaline arteriolosclerosis, as seen on kidney biopsy, are caused by chronic damage from increased capillary hydrostatic pressure in the glomeruli as well as ischemic damage from progressive narrowing of the renal arterioles. Patients with nephrosclerosis present with elevated blood pressure and laboratory findings that suggest impaired renal function, including elevated BUN and creatinine and presence of proteinuria. Some patients may also have microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Ultrasound typically shows small, atrophic kidneys.

Patients with hypertensive nephrosclerosis initially have microalbuminuria but eventually develop macroalbuminuria as the disease progresses.

C) INCORRECT:

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. While this condition is associated with hepatitis C and may cause proteinuria and peripheral edema, membranous nephropathy would also cause hypoalbuminemia, and thickening of the glomerular capillary loops and basal membrane would be evident on light microscopy. The absence of these findings in this patient makes membranous nephropathy an unlikely cause of his end-stage renal disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is potential cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Although this condition is associated with hepatitis C and would cause proteinuria and peripheral edema, MPGN would also cause hypoalbuminemia and basement membrane thickening and splitting with IgG or C3 deposits (“train-track” appearance) would be evident on electron microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a possible cause of chronic kidney disease and secondary hypertension (HTN). Although this patient has multiple risk factors for renal artery stenosis, including HTN, atherosclerotic disease, and diabetes, physical exam findings in renal artery stenosis would include auscultation of a bruit over the flank or abdomen. The absence of an abdominal bruit and the findings from this patient's kidney biopsy suggest his end-stage renal disease is caused by a different mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with peripheral edema, anemia, increased creatinine and BUN, proteinuria, and hyperkalemia. These features are consistent with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: Three days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old woman with resistant hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the office because of decreased urination. She denies dysuria, fevers, or chills. Blood pressure is 133/67 mm Hg. Compared to measurements from one week ago, the glomerular filtration rate is markedly decreased and plasma renin activity is elevated. A duplex ultrasound of the kidneys shows increased systolic flow velocity in both renal arteries when compared to the aorta. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's worsening renal function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the ascending loop of Henle. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not augment the activity of renin.

B) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone acts on the distal convoluted tubules. It does not directly reduce glomerular filtration rate or increase the activity of renin.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that acts on the proximal portion of the distal convoluted tubules. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not increase the activity of renin.

D) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors like enalapril inhibit efferent arteriole constriction, which can lead to a decrease in the GFR and acute kidney injury, as seen here. Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis are especially susceptible to this effect, as the kidneys rely on efferent arteriole constriction to maintain the GFR. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) work in a similar fashion. Therefore, both ARBs and ACEIs are relatively contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a selective beta blocker that is used to treat hypertension. Beta blockers do not exhibit a marked effect on glomerular filtration rate and should decrease, not increase, renin activity at normal doses.
questions.hint: This patient's duplex ultrasound shows findings consistent with renal artery stenosis, which manifests with increased flow velocity from the narrowed artery.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks' gestation presents for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and blood pressure is 165/115 mm Hg. Her blood pressure measured 5 hours ago at home was 160/112 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 28-week gestation. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and hepatic transaminases are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril and angiotensin receptor blockers are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy because they can cause permanent renal damage in the fetus as well as congenital malformations of the cardiovascular system and/or CNS.

B) INCORRECT:

Strenuous exercise (e.g., weight lifting, high-intensity interval training) should be avoided in patients with preeclampsia. However, mild exercise (e.g., walking, stretching) may be beneficial in this patient group. Complete bed rest is associated with an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and is therefore not recommended in patients with hypertensive pregnancy disorders.

C) INCORRECT:

Dietary modifications such as reduction of salt intake and a DASH diet are recommended for all patients with primary hypertension. However, they have not been shown to improve outcomes in patients with gestational hypertension, which is primarily due to placental angiogenic factors that negatively affect maternal endothelial function.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin can be initiated after 12 weeks' gestation to reduce the risk of preeclampsia in patients with certain high-risk features, such as a history of preeclampsia in a previous pregnancy, multiple pregnancy, diabetes mellitus (gestational or nongestational), preexisting hypertension, and/or autoimmune diseases. This patient already meets the diagnostic criteria for preeclampsia with severe features. Aspirin is solely used in the prophylaxis but not in the treatment of preeclampsia.

E) CORRECT:

Antihypertensive therapy should be initiated as soon as possible in patients with preeclampsia with severe features. Available options include intravenous hydralazine, intravenous labetalol, and oral nifedipine. Magnesium sulfate should also be administered for seizure prophylaxis. Patients between 24 weeks' and 34 weeks' gestation should also receive antenatal corticosteroid therapy for fetal maturation.

Management of patients with preeclampsia with severe features who are at < 34 weeks' gestation should be continued on an inpatient basis. Although expectant management is acceptable in these patients, delivery should not be delayed if there is maternal or fetal deterioration.
questions.hint: Preeclampsia with severe features can be diagnosed in patients at > 20 weeks' gestation who present with systolic blood pressure ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 110 mm Hg, even if other abnormalities characteristic of preeclampsia are absent on clinical or diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with hypertension 3 months ago. He walks for 45 minutes daily. His current diet consists mostly of canned tuna and cured meats. His only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While increasing the patient's dose of hydrochlorothiazide may be an option, other measures should be considered first before changing his pharmacological regimen.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, such as metoprolol, are usually not recommended for the initial pharmacotherapy of hypertension because other agents are more effective. Beta blockers are typically only added to the medication regimen if monotherapy with a thiazide diuretic, calcium channel blocker, ACE inhibitor, or angiotensin-receptor blocker is unable to control blood pressure. Despite showing an inadequate response to his single anti-hypertensive medication, this patient has not exhausted all initial management strategies. Moreover, the combination of beta blockers and thiazide diuretics is associated with an increased risk of synergistic adverse metabolic effects (impaired glucose tolerance, dyslipidemia).

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism should always be considered when evaluating a patient with secondary hypertension. However, he has no clinical features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, diaphoresis, diarrhea, etc) and does not meet the criteria for therapy-resistant hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Daily aerobic exercise should always be recommended in patients diagnosed with hypertension as part of lifestyle modification counseling. However, this patient already walks 45 minutes per day, so an additional exercise routine is unlikely to provide much benefit.

E) CORRECT:

Lifestyle modification counseling should always be performed when evaluating a patient with hypertension. Emphasis should be made on addressing modifiable risk factors (diet, exercise, weight loss, smoking cessation). His high-sodium diet (i.e., canned foods and cured meats) likely contributes to his hypertension and should be modified appropriately. This patient should be encouraged to follow a DASH diet, which is proven to reduce blood pressure compared to average American diet or salt-restricted diet alone.

See “Lifestyle changes for managing hypertension” table.
questions.hint: Despite therapy with an antihypertensive drug, this patient continues to have elevated blood pressure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old African American woman comes to the office for a routine examination. She has no history of serious illness and her previous health maintenance examination was within normal limits. Her mother has hypertension. Her respirations are 12/min and blood pressure is 158/89 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After a 5-minute rest, her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has elevated blood pressure readings obtained on a single visit. Remeasuring blood pressure on both arms in 2 weeks is the most appropriate next step to determine if she has hypertension. Hypertension is typically only diagnosed if the average blood pressure of at least two readings from at least two separate visits is elevated or if the average blood pressure recorded on home or ambulatory blood pressure monitoring is elevated. There are two exceptions where hypertension can be diagnosed with a single elevated blood pressure reading, including a single reading of ≥ 180/≥ 120 mm Hg or ≥ 160/≥ 100 mm Hg with known end-organ damage (e.g., myocardial ischemia, kidney injury, hypertensive retinopathy).

Patients should be counseled on the importance of lifestyle modifications (e.g., weight loss, DASH diet, decreasing dietary sodium and alcohol, exercise, and increasing dietary potassium) at the first detection of elevated blood pressure. Individuals with newly diagnosed hypertension should then have the following basic testing to evaluate for potential end-organ damage, further cardiovascular risk factors, and potential causes of secondary hypertension: ECG, CBC, basic metabolic panel, lipid profile, TSH, and urinalysis (to assess for microscopic hematuria and urine protein/creatinine ratio). Because this patient is < 30 years of age, secondary causes of hypertension should be suspected and ruled out.

Key learning point: Hypertension should not be diagnosed based on a single elevated blood pressure reading; repeat measurements on separate visits are required before initiating further evaluation or treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

An ECG should be obtained in all patients with newly diagnosed hypertension. However, as this patient does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension, an ECG is premature at this stage.

An ECG should also be obtained in all patients who present with hypertensive crisis for two reasons: (1) to look for signs of myocardial ischemia, which is a feature of hypertensive emergency requiring ICU admission and the immediate initiation of IV antihypertensive therapy; and (2) because a single blood pressure reading of ≥ 180/≥ 120 mm Hg or ≥ 160/≥ 100 mm Hg with known end-organ damage (e.g., myocardial ischemia, kidney injury, hypertensive retinopathy) meets the criteria for a diagnosis of hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

A thiazide diuretic is an appropriate first-line antihypertensive medication that can be used in combination with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker for individuals diagnosed with stage 2 hypertension. Although this patient has a blood pressure of 155/85 mm Hg, she does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension. Therefore, it is premature to initiate pharmacological treatment at this time.

Previous guidelines recommended the sole use of either thiazide-type diuretics or calcium channel blockers for treating hypertension in Black patients without chronic kidney disease. These recommendations were based on the incorrect assumption that Black individuals have increased salt sensitivity and low renin levels and are therefore particularly responsive to diuretics. Because of this approach, Black patients were less likely to receive renin-angiotensin-aldosterone inhibitors, potentially limiting access to their cardioprotective and renoprotective benefits. The current consensus is that a patient's race or ethnicity should not be the basis for excluding any major antihypertensive class in combination regimens.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal Doppler ultrasonography (alternatively CT angiography) can be used to diagnose renal fibromuscular dysplasia, which is a cause of secondary hypertension. Secondary causes should always be suspected and ruled out, especially in individuals < 30 years or > 55 years with new-onset hypertension. In particular, an elevated blood pressure in a young woman may raise suspicion for fibromuscular dysplasia. However, as this patient does not yet meet the criteria for the diagnosis of hypertension, it is premature to conduct a workup for secondary hypertension at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications such as weight loss (in overweight patients), DASH diet, exercise, a low-sodium (not low-potassium) diet, reducing alcohol intake, and smoking cessation (in order of decreasing effectiveness) are helpful in preventing hypertension and managing milder forms of hypertension, and they should be recommended to all individuals with an elevated blood pressure ≥ 120/80 mm Hg. This patient should therefore be counseled on lifestyle modifications, which includes recommending a low-sodium diet.
questions.hint: This healthy patient presents with elevated blood pressure on routine examination, raising concern for hypertension, which requires an additional diagnostic step.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Four weeks ago, she had increased blood pressure readings of 145/95 mm Hg on both arms. She reports a blood pressure reading of 116/82 mmHg that she measured at home 1 week ago. Pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 148/94 mm Hg on the right arm and 145/91 mm Hg on the left arm. Blood pressure measured 10 minutes later is 144/92 mm Hg on the right arm and 141/89 mm Hg on the left arm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up at the office in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies, including a serum electrolyte panel, should be obtained in all patients with newly diagnosed hypertension. This patient has suspected hypertension based on elevated in-office blood pressure readings; however, the diagnosis must be confirmed before obtaining laboratory testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography can detect renal artery stenosis, which is a common cause of secondary hypertension. However, evaluation for secondary causes is only recommended in patients with findings that suggest secondary hypertension (e.g., severe or resistant hypertension, hypertension associated with electrolyte disorders). Additionally, renal artery stenosis is more common in patients over 65 years of age.

C) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, e.g., lisinopril, are a first-line treatment option for patients with hypertension. Pharmacological therapy is indicated in all adults with systolic blood pressure ≥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg. However, in this patient, the diagnosis has yet to be established and treatment should not be initiated prematurely. In patients with true hypertension, evaluation for end-organ damage, comorbidities, and contraindications should be done before choosing the most suitable treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Ambulatory blood pressure measurement (ABPM) is the preferred method for distinguishing between true hypertension and white coat hypertension in patients who have elevated in-office blood pressure. ABPM records blood pressure at fixed intervals over 24 hours while the patient is carrying out regular activities. In-office readings between ≥ 130/89 mm Hg and ≤ 160/100 mm Hg in combination with out-of-office readings < 130/80 mm Hg confirm white coat hypertension (see “Interpretation of blood pressure readings “ table). Antihypertensive treatment is not necessary for patients with white coat hypertension. Instead, lifestyle modifications and cardiovascular risk reduction should be implemented. A repeat ABPM or home blood pressure monitoring (HBPM) should be done annually to monitor for progression to sustained hypertension. HBPM, an alternative option for recording out-of-office measurements, is done manually, requires patient training, and only records daytime blood pressure.

Out-of-office blood pressure measurement is also indicated in all patients with elevated in-office blood pressure readings to confirm hypertension prior to initiating antihypertensive treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although regular follow-up is necessary for patients with white coat hypertension, true hypertension must first be ruled out in these individuals. Reassurance alone in patients with white coat hypertension would not be sufficient, however, as lifestyle modifications and cardiovascular risk reduction are necessary interventions.
questions.hint: This otherwise healthy patient presents with repeatedly elevated blood pressure readings in a clinical setting and a normal blood pressure reading measured elsewhere. It is important to determine whether the elevated readings are caused by anxiety, (i.e., white coat hypertension) or by true hypertension.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 65-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. Three weeks ago, his blood pressure was 160/80 mm Hg. Subsequent home blood pressure measurements at days 5, 10, and 15 found: 165/75 mm Hg, 162/82 mm Hg, and 170/80 mm Hg, respectively. Pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 165/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including thyroid function studies, serum electrolytes, and serum creatinine, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's elevated blood pressure?

choices.text: Increase in left ventricular end-diastolic volume

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated LV end-diastolic volume, as seen in aortic regurgitation (AR), increases stroke volume and can also widen pulse pressure. However, AR alone would not cause this patient's hypertension, and a high-pitched, early diastolic murmur would be expected.

B) CORRECT:

A decrease in arterial compliance secondary to age-related reduction in arterial elasticity and increased stiffness is common in individuals > 60 years old. This decrease results in isolated systolic hypertension, which is characterized by a wide pulse pressure, as seen in this patient. Treatment with an antihypertensive agent, such as a thiazide diuretic or calcium channel blocker, should be initiated to decrease the risk of a cardiovascular event (e.g., myocardial infarction, stroke, or renal dysfunction).

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease in renal artery blood flow would activate the renin-angiotensin system and result in renovascular hypertension. Important causes of reduced renal artery blood flow include renal artery stenosis, external compression of the renal arteries (e.g., by a tumor or cyst), atherosclerosis of the renal arteries, and fibromuscular dysplasia. While atherosclerosis of the renal arteries should be considered given the patient's age, his normal diastolic pressures make another underlying cause more likely. Furthermore, only bilateral renal artery disease resulting in a significant decrease in GFR would manifest with hypertension; this patient's normal creatinine makes such a decrease unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is the most common cause of secondary hypertension and classically manifests with resistant hypertension and hypokalemia. The blood pressure seen in primary hyperaldosteronism is often markedly elevated and causes increases in both systolic and diastolic pressures. This patient's isolated systolic hypertension and normal lab values make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A decrease in baroreceptor sensitivity is the underlying mechanism of orthostatic hypotension. Unlike this patient's asymptomatic hypertension, it is characterized by autonomic dysfunction and insufficient counter-regulation after postural changes that leads to dizziness and syncope after standing up.
questions.hint: This elderly patient has a wide pulse pressure with elevated systolic blood pressure readings and normal diastolic pressures.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of 24-hour blood pressure monitoring results. Over the last 3 months, she has had intermittent nausea, decreased appetite, and increasing weakness and fatigue during the day. She has been treated twice for kidney stones within the past year. Her current medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, and furosemide. Her blood pressure is 152/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Na+

141 mEq/L


Cl−

101 mEq/L


K+

4.5 mEq/L


HCO3−

24 mEq/L


Calcium
12.9 mg/dL


A 24-hour blood pressure monitoring indicates elevated nocturnal blood pressure. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol is diagnostic of Cushing syndrome (hypercortisolism), which can cause treatment-resistant secondary hypertension with lethargy and muscle weakness. However, it typically also manifests with central obesity, thin and easily bruisable skin, abdominal striae, and proximal muscle atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum aldosterone-to-renin ratio indicates primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome). Primary hyperaldosteronism can cause secondary hypertension with features of hypokalemia (e.g., fatigue and muscle weakness). However, this patient's potassium level is normal. Moreover, hypercalcemia and symptoms such as recurrent renal stones or gastrointestinal complaints are not expected in Conn syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) would indicate hyperthyroidism, which is an important cause of treatment-resistant secondary hypertension and may present with weakness and fatigue. Hyperthyroidism could also explain this patient's hypercalcemia, as thyroid hormones have osteoclastic activity. However, decreased appetite is not typical of hyperthyroidism, and this patient is lacking other symptoms that are expected in the setting of thyroid hormone excess (e.g., heat intolerance, weight loss, diarrhea, tachycardia, tremor).

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased renal blood flow due to renal artery stenosis or fibromuscular dysplasia is a common cause of treatment-resistant secondary hypertension, which is often accompanied by fatigue and weakness. Decreased perfusion triggers the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and causes persistent vasoconstriction as well as volume retention. However, renal artery stenosis does not explain this patient's hypercalcemia or recurrent kidney stones. Furthermore, constantly elevated aldosterone would lead to hypokalemia, which this patient does not have.

E) CORRECT:

Increased serum parathyroid hormone is characteristic of primary hyperparathyroidism, a known cause of secondary hypertension. Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have hypercalcemia and can present with recurrent nephrolithiasis, nausea, decreased appetite, fatigue, and weakness. Hypercalcemia is thought to cause hypertension by affecting vascular reactivity and interrupting day-night blood pressure regulation.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is also a common finding in MEN 1 and MEN 2A. MEN 2A often also involves pheochromocytoma, another possible (concurrent) cause of secondary hypertension that should be considered in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has resistant hypertension despite treatment with three antihypertensive drugs, which should raise concern for secondary hypertension. She also has nephrolithiasis, nausea and decreased appetite, fatigue, and weakness.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after an office blood pressure reading 3 months ago of 139/86 mmHg. He has since adhered to a new diet and exercise regimen, but his blood pressure has consistently been above 135/85 mm Hg on multiple home measurements. He reports that he often experiences lightheadedness. He takes metformin for type 2 diabetes mellitus. He appears frail. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 138/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no signs of left ventricular hypertrophy and no other abnormalities. After a 5-minute rest, his blood pressure is 139/86 mm Hg. Serum creatinine concentration is 1.3 mg/dL, and urinalysis shows an albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 50 mg/g (N < 30). An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm without left ventricular hypertrophy. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) are the preferred diuretic in patients with symptomatic heart failure and chronic kidney disease (if GFR < 30 mL/min). Loop diuretics are typically second-line antihypertensive agents and should be used with caution in patients > 60 years of age because of the increased risk of orthostatic hypotension and falls in this population.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., chlorthalidone) are the preferred initial antihypertensive agents in patients with isolated systolic hypertension. Thiazide diuretics may be used as first-line agents in individuals with diabetes mellitus who do not have albuminuria. However, this patient has stage 1 hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and microalbuminuria, making another initial pharmacotherapy more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs), e.g., lisinopril, are the preferred initial treatment for individuals with arterial hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and microalbuminuria. ACEIs lower intraglomerular pressure and help slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy and kidney dysfunction.

Monotherapy is typically recommended as initial management for stage 1 hypertension. First-line medications for primary hypertension are ACEIs, thiazide diuretics, angiotensin receptor blockers, and dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha blockers (e.g., prazosin) are the preferred antihypertensive agents in individuals with pheochromocytoma and are used as adjunctive therapy in those with benign prostatic hyperplasia. They are typically used as second-line agents for the management of hypertension. In individuals > 60 years of age, alpha blockers should be used with caution because of the increased risk of orthostatic hypotension and falls.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., carvedilol) are not recommended as first-line antihypertensive agents unless indicated for a significant cardiac condition (e.g., ischemic heart disease, heart failure). In patients with diabetes mellitus, these drugs should be used with caution because they can mask symptoms of hypoglycemia. Additionally, in individuals > 60 years of age, beta blockers are less effective at preventing cardiovascular events. Therefore, beta blockers are typically reserved for second-line management of hypertension.
questions.hint: Initial monotherapy with an antihypertensive agent can be considered in the management of stage 1 hypertension.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes and stage 2 hypertension. He has been taking a low-dose thiazide diuretic for six months, but his blood pressure remains around 150/90 mmHg. He complains of occasional dizziness when standing but otherwise feels well. He has no known medication allergies and adheres to his medication regimen (see lab results).

Blood pressure
150/90 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
112 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Albuminuria
Mild
Normal: <30 mg/g, Mild: 30-300 mg/g, Severe: >300 mg/g


Hemoglobin A1C
7.9 %
4.7 - 5.6 %



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of thiazide diuretic
Add a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker
Begin a selective beta-1 adrenergic antagonist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing the thiazide diuretic dose might lower blood pressure but does not address the renal protection needed in diabetic patients with albuminuria. Thiazides lack renoprotective benefits and may worsen orthostatic hypotension, as indicated by the patient's dizziness. The mechanism of thiazides does not address endothelial dysfunction and intraglomerular hypertension in diabetic nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers lower blood pressure but are not first-line for diabetes with nephropathy. They lack renoprotective effects and may exacerbate dizziness due to orthostatic hypotension or bradycardia. Agents modulating the renin-angiotensin system are preferred for their renal benefits.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with type 2 diabetes and mild albuminuria, adding an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor is crucial for both blood pressure control and renal protection. ACE inhibitors reduce intraglomerular pressure, decreasing proteinuria and slowing diabetic nephropathy progression. They modulate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, reducing systemic hypertension and offering cardiovascular benefits. This approach aligns with guidelines recommending ACE inhibitors for diabetic patients with microalbuminuria to achieve comprehensive risk reduction.

Key learning point: In patients with hypertension not controlled by a thiazide diuretic alone, adding an ACE inhibitor is a preferred strategy, especially if there are concerns about glucose metabolism or renal protection.

D) INCORRECT:

Selective beta-1 blockers lower blood pressure but do not offer renal protection in diabetic nephropathy. They may interfere with glycemic control and mask hypoglycemia symptoms. The patient's dizziness suggests that further cardiac output reduction could worsen orthostatic symptoms, making beta blockers less favorable.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has a blood pressure above the 95th percentile at one office visit. Examination is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Start lifestyle modifications and medication concurrently
Obtain repeat blood pressure measurements on two additional visits
Obtain renal imaging without further delay

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While lifestyle modifications are important in managing pediatric hypertension, medication should not be started after only one elevated reading. Hypertension diagnosis requires confirmation with repeated measurements. Medication is reserved for confirmed, sustained hypertension, especially with stage 2 hypertension or target organ damage.

B) INCORRECT:

A single elevated blood pressure reading in a child is insufficient for diagnosing hypertension. Pediatric hypertension requires confirmation with readings on at least three separate occasions. The absence of abnormal findings suggests no immediate need for pharmacological intervention, as guidelines recommend thorough evaluation before starting treatment.

C) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients, blood pressure is assessed based on age, sex, and height percentiles. A single elevated reading can be influenced by transient factors like anxiety or improper technique. Guidelines recommend confirming elevated blood pressure on at least two additional visits to ensure persistence before diagnosing hypertension. This approach prevents overdiagnosis and unnecessary interventions, allowing for accurate assessment and informed decisions regarding lifestyle modifications or further evaluation.

Key learning point: Hypertension in children is diagnosed when blood pressure is greater than the 95th percentile for age, sex, and height on three separate occasions.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal imaging is used to evaluate secondary causes of hypertension, but in a child with one elevated reading and an unremarkable examination, the focus should be on confirming the diagnosis with repeated measurements. Imaging is premature without evidence of persistent hypertension or clinical findings suggestive of renal pathology.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with significant obesity is brought in for routine evaluation. Which complication is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is an autoimmune condition causing pancreatic β-cell destruction and insulin deficiency. It is not associated with obesity, which predisposes to insulin resistance rather than autoimmune β-cell destruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary enuresis, or persistent bed-wetting, is typically due to developmental factors, genetic predisposition, or delayed bladder control maturation, not metabolic disturbances. Obesity-related complications are more often metabolic or cardiovascular, not urologic.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperventilation syndrome is linked to anxiety or panic episodes, causing respiratory alkalosis. The vignette describes an obese child without distress or symptoms suggesting hyperventilation. Obesity-related complications are typically metabolic or cardiovascular.

D) CORRECT:

In pediatric obesity, adipose tissue acts as an endocrine organ, secreting cytokines and adipokines that promote systemic inflammation and insulin resistance. This leads to hyperinsulinemia, increasing renal sodium retention and stimulating the sympathetic nervous system, contributing to elevated blood pressure. The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system activation further exacerbates vasoconstriction and fluid retention. These mechanisms contribute to early hypertension development in obese children, making it a significant complication of childhood obesity.

Key learning point: Hypertension is a recognized complication of childhood obesity, while primary enuresis, type 1 diabetes, and hyperventilation syndrome are not directly linked to obesity.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents for evaluation of persistently elevated blood pressure despite following a low-salt diet and aerobic exercise routine for the past three months. He was diagnosed with hypertension at that time, with baseline blood pressure readings around 150/90 mmHg. He has no significant past medical history and denies any symptoms of secondary causes of hypertension. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. Laboratory studies show normal serum electrolytes and a serum creatinine of 88 μmol/L (reference range: 62–106 μmol/L) (see report).

Blood pressure
158/96 mmHg

ECG: Normal sinus rhythm without evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Combination therapy with an ACE inhibitor and an angiotensin II receptor blocker
Single-agent therapy with an alpha-1 blocker
Combination therapy with an ACE inhibitor and a long-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combining an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) does not provide additional benefit in uncomplicated hypertension and increases risks such as hyperkalemia and renal impairment. This combination is not recommended for patients with preserved renal function and no secondary indications.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers reduce heart rate and myocardial contractility but are not preferred as initial monotherapy for uncomplicated hypertension without cardiovascular comorbidities. They offer less protection against stroke and cardiovascular outcomes compared to thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitors, or calcium channel blockers.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 blockers inhibit sympathetic-mediated vasoconstriction but are not first-line for uncomplicated hypertension. They are typically used in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia or when other agents are contraindicated. Adverse effects like orthostatic hypotension make them less favorable compared to ACE inhibitors, ARBs, thiazide diuretics, or calcium channel blockers.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has resistant hypertension, as evidenced by persistently elevated blood pressure despite lifestyle modifications. Combining an ACE inhibitor with a long-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is recommended for such cases. The ACE inhibitor reduces angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction and aldosterone-driven sodium retention, while the calcium channel blocker induces vasodilation by relaxing vascular smooth muscle. This combination targets different pathways in blood pressure regulation, providing a synergistic effect for optimal control.

Key learning point: In patients with newly diagnosed hypertension not controlled by lifestyle modifications, combination therapy with medications from different classes, such as an ACE inhibitor and a calcium channel blocker, is often recommended for better blood pressure control.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes. Over the past six months, his blood pressure readings have averaged 145/90 mm Hg. Recent urinalysis shows microalbuminuria. He has no known drug allergies. Physical examination reveals mild bilateral pedal edema but no other abnormalities. Laboratory tests indicate normal electrolytes and an eGFR of 68 mL/min/1.73 m2.
Which of the following is the most appropriate antihypertensive therapy to initiate in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, effectively lowers blood pressure through vasodilation but lacks renoprotective benefits. In patients with type 2 diabetes and microalbuminuria, agents that reduce intraglomerular pressure and proteinuria are preferred. Amlodipine can also cause peripheral edema, which is relevant given the patient's existing mild pedal edema.

B) CORRECT:

Ramipril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, is effective in managing hypertension and provides renoprotective effects in diabetic patients. It reduces angiotensin II formation, leading to efferent arteriolar dilation, decreased intraglomerular pressure, and limited kidney injury progression, as indicated by microalbuminuria. This is particularly beneficial in patients with type 2 diabetes and mildly reduced estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). Additionally, ramipril lowers aldosterone levels, reducing fluid retention and offering cardiovascular protection, which is crucial for diabetic patients at increased cardiovascular risk.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors like ramipril are preferred for managing hypertension in patients with type 2 diabetes due to their renal protective effects and ability to slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, a loop diuretic, promotes diuresis and is used in volume overload conditions. While it can lower blood pressure by reducing plasma volume, it does not provide the renal protection needed in diabetic nephropathy with microalbuminuria. The patient's mild pedal edema does not warrant furosemide use, as the primary concern is renal protection.

D) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol, a nonselective beta-blocker with alpha-blocking properties, lowers blood pressure by reducing heart rate and vascular resistance. However, it lacks the renoprotective effects needed for diabetic nephropathy. Beta-blockers can also impair insulin sensitivity and mask hypoglycemia symptoms, making them less suitable for diabetic patients without specific cardiovascular indications.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine check-up. He has a 4-year history of type 2 diabetes treated with metformin. He denies chest pain or dyspnea. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease. He is not on any antihypertensive therapy. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild peripheral neuropathy (see lab results).

Blood pressure
150/92 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, random
10.5 mmol/L
3.9 - 5.5 mmol/L


Urine




 Microalbuminuria
Present
< 30 mg/g creatinine



Which medication is most appropriate to initiate for blood pressure control in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine, a direct arteriolar vasodilator, is typically used in hypertensive emergencies or specific situations like pregnancy. It lacks the renal protective effects necessary for diabetic patients with microalbuminuria. Additionally, it can cause adverse effects such as reflex tachycardia and fluid retention, making it less suitable for long-term management in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine, a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, effectively reduces blood pressure through arterial vasodilation. However, it lacks the renoprotective benefits needed for patients with diabetic nephropathy, such as reducing intraglomerular pressure and proteinuria. ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are preferred for their ability to slow renal deterioration in diabetic patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, effectively lowers blood pressure but lacks the renoprotective effects needed for diabetic patients with microalbuminuria. It may also exacerbate metabolic issues like hyperglycemia, which is concerning in diabetes. ACE inhibitors or ARBs are preferred for their renal benefits in diabetic nephropathy.

D) CORRECT:

Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, is the preferred choice for hypertensive patients with diabetes, especially those with microalbuminuria. It offers renal protection by reducing intraglomerular pressure through efferent arteriolar dilation, slowing the progression of diabetic nephropathy. Additionally, ACE inhibitors effectively control blood pressure and address both cardiovascular and renal complications in diabetic patients, making them ideal for this clinical scenario.

Key learning point: In diabetic patients with hypertension, an ACE inhibitor is recommended to achieve blood pressure control and provide renal protection.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine visit. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and reports minimal exercise and frequent fast food consumption. She has no history of diabetes, chronic kidney disease, or cardiovascular disease. Her BMI is 32. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory tests show normal renal function and lipid levels.

Blood pressure
136/84 mm Hg

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend dietary changes, encourage weight reduction, and advise smoking cessation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors lower blood pressure by reducing vascular resistance and are used in overt hypertension, diabetic nephropathy, or heart failure. This patient's blood pressure is modestly elevated, and she lacks comorbid conditions like diabetes or chronic kidney disease that would benefit from ACE inhibitors. Her normal laboratory values and absence of target-organ damage suggest prioritizing lifestyle modifications over pharmacologic intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a first-line antihypertensive for established hypertension. However, the patient's blood pressure of 136/84 mm Hg is within stage 1 hypertension, and there is no evidence of end-organ damage or high atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk. Her profile suggests focusing on non-pharmacologic interventions like diet and exercise. Pharmacologic therapy would be premature without persistent blood pressure elevation confirmed by repeated measurements.

C) INCORRECT:

Daily aspirin is considered for primary prevention in high cardiovascular risk individuals. This patient, with risk factors like obesity and smoking, does not have a high enough cardiovascular risk to justify aspirin use, especially without atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease or diabetes. The risk of bleeding may outweigh benefits in low to moderate risk individuals, emphasizing lifestyle modifications over aspirin.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with borderline elevated blood pressure and cardiovascular risk factors like obesity and smoking, lifestyle modifications are crucial. The DASH diet, emphasizing fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy, can lower blood pressure by reducing sodium intake. Weight loss improves endothelial function and reduces blood pressure by decreasing the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and sympathetic nervous system. Smoking cessation reduces cardiovascular risk by eliminating nicotine's vasoconstrictive and pro-inflammatory effects. Current guidelines recommend lifestyle changes as first-line interventions for early hypertension without target organ damage.

Key learning point: In patients with stage 1 hypertension and additional cardiovascular risk factors, lifestyle modifications including weight loss and dietary changes are the first-line management strategy before initiating pharmacologic therapy.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents for a follow-up appointment. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes and has had progressively increasing blood pressure readings over the past six months. He is currently taking metformin and a thiazide diuretic. Physical examination shows mild bilateral pedal edema. He has no known drug allergies (see lab results).


Heart rate
78/min


Blood pressure
156/94 mmHg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
130 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Potassium
4.6 mmol/L
3.5 - 5.1 mmol/L


Urine




 Protein
2+
Absent


 Albumin-to-creatinine ratio
250 mg/g
< 30 mg/g



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics are effective for uncomplicated hypertension but less so in diabetic nephropathy with renal impairment and proteinuria. Increasing the dose may modestly improve blood pressure but does not address the intraglomerular hemodynamic changes or proteinuria. Thiazides are also less effective with declining renal function.

B) INCORRECT:

Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers lower blood pressure but lack the renoprotective effects of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system-targeting medications. In diabetic patients with kidney involvement, reducing intraglomerular pressure is crucial, which these agents do not achieve.

C) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone antagonists are used in treatment-resistant hypertension and heart failure but carry a risk of hyperkalemia in renal impairment. In diabetic nephropathy, therapies reducing intraglomerular pressure and albuminuria are more effective.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with type 2 diabetes and kidney involvement, such as elevated albumin-to-creatinine ratio and proteinuria, an ACE inhibitor is preferred. This class of medication slows diabetic nephropathy progression by reducing intraglomerular pressure through efferent arteriole dilation, thereby lowering proteinuria and preserving kidney function. Additionally, ACE inhibitors aid in achieving tighter blood pressure control, crucial for reducing cardiovascular risk in diabetic patients.

Key learning point: In patients with diabetes, hypertension, and proteinuria, ACE inhibitors are recommended for their blood pressure-lowering and renal protective effects.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 19-year-old female college athlete with no medical history or current medications for hypertension. Her current blood pressure is 182/100 mm Hg, and previous readings have been similarly elevated, including 178/85 mm Hg last week and 185/90 mm Hg 6 months ago. At home last week, her right upper extremity blood pressure was 162/95 mm Hg. Blood pressure measurements are similar in both the upper and lower extremities. On examination, her dorsalis pedis pulses are bounding and symmetric, with no radiofemoral delay. Laboratory investigations, including complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid function tests, and inflammatory markers, are all within normal limits. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma is a rare cause of secondary hypertension. About half of patients with pheochromocytoma have paroxysmal hypertension. Renal artery fibromuscular dysplasia is a more common cause of secondary hypertension.

B) CORRECT:

About 5% of cases of hypertension in adults aged 18 to 39 have a secondary cause, most often thyroid disease, parenchymal kidney disease, or fibromuscular dysplasia. Hypertension in a patient in this age range increases the likelihood of secondary hypertension. If the patient is asymptomatic and has normal laboratory findings, the most likely diagnosis is renovascular hypertension related to fibromuscular dysplasia.

Key learning point: The most common cause of persistent renovascular hypertension in an asymptomatic young woman whose thyroid function, electrolyte levels, inflammatory markers, and kidney function are all normal is fibromuscular dysplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that can cause hypertension from renal artery involvement; however, patients usually have systemic symptoms, peripheral pulses may be diminished, and inflammatory markers are usually abnormal.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism causing secondary hypertension is often associated with metabolic alkalosis, mild hypernatremia, and hypokalemia, and it is more common in older patients.

E) INCORRECT:

In aortic coarctation, blood pressure is typically lower in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up after a preemployment electrocardiogram (figure) was performed. He has not seen a health care provider in many years. He reports no significant medical history, feels well, and does not use tobacco or alcohol. He takes no medications. His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a sustained apical impulse with no audible murmurs. Kidney function and serum electrolyte levels are normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with LVH but not hypertension. In addition, patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and significant left ventricular outflow-tract obstruction often have a murmur related to this obstruction or a mitral regurgitation murmur related to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma that is sufficiently severe and chronic to cause LVH typically produces a range of symptoms, including headaches and palpitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Although aortic stenosis can cause LVH, it does not cause hypertension and is easily identified by the presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

D) CORRECT:

This asymptomatic patient has primary hypertension, with electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). A sustained apical impulse indicates that LVH is present. The patient’s echocardiogram would be likely to show thickened LV walls and an elevated LV mass index.

Key learning point: The cardiac examination finding of a sustained apical impulse is most consistent with a diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a rare cause of hypertension and resultant LVH and is often associated with impaired kidney function.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up after a blood pressure reading of 148/98 mm Hg at her last health maintenance visit four weeks ago. She reports feeling well. She has a history of migraine with aura of moderate to severe intensity, and over the past year, her headaches have increased in frequency to 1–2 times per week. Her blood pressure today is 143/92 mm Hg, and a repeat sitting blood pressure 20 minutes later is 145/94 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) are considered first-line treatment for hypertension. However, this patient with a history of worsening migraine headaches would benefit more from an alternative antihypertensive that can treat both of her medical problems.
